div.p: A King and no King. Acted at the globe, by his majesty's servants.
Written by Francis Beaumont, and John Fletcher.
At London printed for Thomas Walkley, and are to be sold at his shop at the eagle and child in Britain-purse. 1619.

div.head: To the right worshipful, and worthy knight, sir Henry Nevill.
div.p: I present, or rather return unto your view, that which formerly hath been received from you, hereby effecting what you did desire: to commend the work in my unlearned method, were rather to detract from it, than to give it any luster. It sufficeth it hath your worship's approbation and patronage, to the commendation of the authors, and encouragement of their further labours: and thus wholly committing myself and it to your worship's dispose I rest, ever ready to do you service, not only in the like, but in what i may.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Bessus, the King has made a fair hand on't, has ended the wars at a blow, would my sword had a close basket hilt to hold wine, and the blade would make knives, for we shall have nothing but eating and drinking.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: We that are commanders shall do well enough.

sp.speaker: M●r.
sp.p: Faith bes. such commanders as thou may, I had as live set thee perdue for a pudding i'th' dark, as Alexander the great.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I love these jests exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I think thou lovest them better than quarrelling Bessus, he say so much i'thy behalf, and yet thou art valiant enough upon a retreat, I think thou wouldst kill any man that stopped thee, and thou couldst.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: But was not this a brave combat Mardonius?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, didst thou see't?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: You stood with me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I did so, but methought thou wink'st every blow they strake.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Well, I believe there are better soldiers than I, that never saw two princes fight in lists.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: By my troth I think so too Bessus, many a thousand, but certainly all that are worse than thou have seen as much.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: 'Twas bravely done of our King.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, if he had not ended the wars, I am glad thou dar'st talk of such dangerous businesses.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: To take a prince prisoner in the heart of his own country in single combat.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: See how thy blood cruddles at this, I think thou wouldst be contented to be beaten in this passion.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Shall I tell you truly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I could willingly venture for it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Umh, no venture neither good Bessus.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Let me not live, if I do not think it is a braver piece of service, then that I'm so famed for.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why art thou famed for any valour?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I famed, ay, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am very heartily glad on't. I have been with thee ever since thou cam'st ath' wars, and this is the first word that ever I heard on't, prithee who fames thee?

sp.speaker: Bes
sp.p: The Christian world.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis heathenishly done of them, in my conscience thou deserv'st it not.

sp.speaker: Bes
sp.p: Yes, I ha' done good service.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I do not know how thou mayst wait of a man in's chamber, or thy agility in shifting a trencher, but otherwise no service good Bessus.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: You saw me do the service yourself.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not so hasty sweet Bessus, where was it, is the place vanished.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: At Bessus desperate redemption.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Bessus desperate redemption, where's that.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: There where I redeemed the day, the place bears my name.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Prithee who christened it.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: The soldier:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
If I were not a very merely disposed man, what would become of thee: one that had but a grain of collar in the whole composition of his body would send thee of an errand to the worms, for putting thy name upon that field: did not I beat thee there i'th' head, a'th troops with a truncheon, because thou wouldst needs run away with thy company,
when we should charge the enemy.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: True, but I did not run.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Right Bessus, I beat thee out on't.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: But came not I up when the day was gone, and redeemed all?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Thou knowest, and so do I, thou meanest to fly, and thy fear making thee mistake, thou ranst upon the enemy, and a hot charge thou gavest, as I'll do thee right, thou art furious in running away, and I think we owe thy fear for our victory. If I were the King, and were sure thou wouldst mistake always, and run away upon the enemy, thou shouldst be general by this light.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: You'll never leave this till I fall foul.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No more such words dear Bessus: for though I have ever known thee a coward, and therefore durst never strike thee; yet if thou proceed'st, I will allow thee valiant, and beat thee.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Come, come, our king's a brave fellow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He is so Bessus, I wonder how thou comest to know it: but if thou wert a man of understanding, I would tell thee he is vainglorious, and humble, and angry, and patient, and merry, and dull, and joyful, and sorrowful, in extremities in an hour: do not think me thy friend for this, for if I cared who knew it, thou shouldst not hear it Bessus: here he is with the prey in his foot.

div.stage: Enter Arbaces and Tigranes, with attendants.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Thy sadness(Brave Tigranes) takes away
From my fall victory; am I become
Of so small fame, that any man should grieve
When I o'ercome him: they that placed me here,
Intended it an honour large enough
For the most valiant living; but to dare
Oppose me single, though he lost the day,
What should afflict you, you are free as I,
To be my prisoner, is to be more free,
Than you were formerly; and never think
The man I held worthy to combat me,
Shall be used servilely: thy ransom is
to take my only sister to thy wife;
A heavy one Tigranes: for she is
A lady that the neighbour princes send
Blanks to fetch home: I have been too unkind
To her Tigranes, she but nine year old,
I left her, and ne'er saw her since: your wars
Have held me long, and taught me, though a youth,
The way to victory: she was a pretty child
Then, I was little better; but now fame
Cries loudly on her, and my messengers
Make me believe she is a miracle;
She'll make you shrink as I did, with a stroke
But of her eye Tigranes.
Is it the course of
Iberia, to use their prisoners thus?
Had fortune thrown my name above Arbaces,
I should not thus have talked: for in Armenia
We hold it base; you should have kept your temper,
Till you saw home again; where 'tis the fashion
Perhaps to brag.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Be you my witness earth:
Need I to brag, doth not this captive prince
Speak me sufficiently, and all the acts
That I have wrought upon his suffering land?
Should I then boast? Where lies that foot of ground
Within his whole realm, that I have not passed
Fighting, and conquering? Far then from me
Be ostentation: I could tell the world
How I have laid his kingdom desolate
With this sole arm, propped by divinity,
Stripped him out of his glories, and have sent
The pride of all his youth to people graves,
And made his virgins languish for their loves;
If I would brag, should I that have the power
To teach the neighbour world humility,
Mix with vain glory.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: In deed this is none?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Tigranes, no; did I but take delight
to stretch my deeds as others do on words,
I could amaze my hearers ▪

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: So you do:

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: But he shall wrong his, and my modesty
That thinks me apt to boast: after an act
Fit for a god to do upon his foe,
A little glory in a soldier's mouth,
Is well becoming, be it far from vain.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Its pity that valour should be thus drunk.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: I offer you my sister, and you answer,
I do insult: a lady that no suit
Nor treasure, nor thy crown could purchase thee,
But that thou foughtst with me.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Though this be worse
Than that you spoke before, it strikes not me
But that you think to over-grace me with
The marriage of your sister, troubles me,
I would give worlds for ransoms were they mine,
Rather than have her.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: See if I insult
That am the conqueror, and for a ransom
Offer rich treasure to the conquered,
Which he refuses, and I bear his scorn.
It cannot be self flattery to say,
The daughters of your country set by her
Would see their shame; run home, and blush to death
At their own foulness, yet she is not fair,
Nor beautiful, those words express her not,
They say her looks are something excellent,
That wants a name yet: were she odious
Her birth deserves the empire of the world.
Sister to such a brother, that hath ta'en
Victory prisoner, and throughout the earth
Carries her bound; and should he let her loose,
She durst not leave him. Nature did her wrong
To print continual conquest on her cheeks,
And make no man worthy for her to take,
But me that am too near her; and as strangely
she did for me: but you will think I brag.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do I'll be sworn. Thy valour and thy passions severed, would have made two excellent fellows in their kinds: I know not whether I should be sorry thou art so valiant, or so passionate ▪ would one of 'em were away.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Do I refuse her that I doubt her worth ▪
Were she as virtuous as she would be thought,
So perfect, that no own of her own sex
Would find a want, had she so tempting fair,
That she could wish it off her damning souls,
I would pay any ransom, twenty-times,
Rather than meet her married in my bed:
Perhaps I have a love, where I have fixed
Mine eyes, not to be moved, and she on me ▪
I am not fickle:

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Is that all the cause?
Think you, you can so knit yourself in love
To any other, that her searching sight
Cannot dissolve it? So before you tried
You thought yourself a match for me in fight:
Trust me Tigranes she can do as much
In peace, as I in war; she'll conquer too
You shall see, if you have the power to stand
The force of her swift looks, if you dislike,
I'll send you home with love, and name your ransom
Some other way: but if she be your choice
She frees you: to Ileria you must.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Sir, I have learned a prisoner's sufferance,
And will obey, but give me leave to talk
In private with some friends before I go.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Some two await him forth, and see him safe,
But let him freely send for whom he please,
And none dare to disturb his conference:
I will not have him know what bondage isExe.
Till he be free from me. This prince Mardonius
Is full of wisdom, valour, all the grace's
Man can receive.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And yet you conquered him?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: And yet I conquered him, and could have done
Hadst thou joined with him, though thy name in arms
Be great; must all men that are virtuous
Think suddenly to match themselves with me:
I conquered him, and bravely; did I not?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: And please your majesty I was afraid at first.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: When wert thou other?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: That you would not have spied your best advantages, for your majesty in my opinion lay too high methinks , under favour, you should have lain thus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Like a tailor at a wake.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: And then, if't please your majesty to remember, at one time, by my troth, I wished myself with you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: By my troth thou wouldst have sunk 'em both out oath lifts.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What to do?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: To put your majesty in mind of an occasion; you lay thus, and Tigranes falsified a blow at your leg, which you by doing thus avoided; but if you had whipped up your leg thus, and reached him on th'ear, you had made the blood run about's head.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What country-fence-school didst thou learn that at?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Puffed, did I not take him nobly?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why you did, and you have talked enough on't.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Talk enough,
While you confine my words, by heaven and earth,
I were much better be a King of beasts
Then such a people: if I had not patience
Above a god, I should be called a tyrant
Throughout the world. They will offend to death
Each minute: let me hear thee speak again
And thou art earth again: why this is like
Tigranes' speech ▪ that needs would say, I bragged.
Bessus he said I bragged.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Why dost thou laugh?
By all the world I me grown ridiculous
to my own subjects: tie me to a chair
And jest at me, but I shall make a start
And punish some, that other will take heed
How they are haughty; who will answer me?
He said I boasted, speak Mardonius,
Did I? He will not answer: oh my temper!
I give you thanks above, that taught my heart
Patience, I can endure his silence; what will none
Vouchsafe to give me audience, am I grown
To such a poor respect or do you mean
To break my wind, speak, speak soon one of you ▪
Or else by heaven,

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: So please your,

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.l: Monstrous,
I cannot be heard out, they cut me off
As if I were too saucy; I will live
In woods, and talk to trees they will allow me
To end what I begin. The meanest subject
Can find a freedom to discharge his soul,
And not I, now it is a time to speak,
I harken.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: May it please,

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I mean not you,
Did not I stop you once? but I am grown
To balk, but I desire, let another speak.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: I hope your majesty,

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Thou drawest thy words
That I must wait an hour, where other men
Can hear in instants; throw your words away
Quick, and to purpose, I have told you this.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: An't please your majesty:

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Wilt thou devour me? this is such a rudeness
As yet you never showed me, and I want
Power to command me, else Mardonius
Would speak at my request; were you my King,
I would have answered at your word Mardonius,
I pray you speak, and true y, did I boast?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Truth will offend you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: You take all great care what will offend me,
When you dare to utter such things as these.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You told Tigranes, you had won his land
With that sole arm propped by divinity:
Was not that bragging, and a wrong to us
That daily ventured lives?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: O that thy name
Were great as mine, would I had paid my wealth,
It were as great, that I might combat thee;
I would through all the regions habitable
Search thee, and having found thee, with my sword
Drive thee about the world, till I had met
Some place that yet man's curiosity
Hath missed of; there, there would I strike thee dead:
Forgotten of mankind, such funeral rites
As beasts would give thee thou shouldst have

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.l: The King
Rage ▪ extremely, shall we slink away;
He'll strike us:

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Content.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: There I would make you know was this sole arm,
I grant you were my instruments, and did
As I commanded you, but was this arm
Moved you like wheels, it moved you as it pleased:
Whither slip you now? what are you too good
To wait on me? I had need have temper
That rule such people; I have nothing left
At my own choice, I would I might be private:
Mean men enjoy themselves, but 'tis our curse,
To have a tumult that out of their loves
Will wait on us whether we will or no;
Will you be gone? why here they stand like death,
My word moves nothing.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Must we go?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.l: I pray you leave me sirs, I'm proud of this,
That they will be entreated from my sight:
Why now they leave me all: Mardonius,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Will you leave me quite alone? methinks
Civility should teach you more than this,
If I were but your friend: stay here, and wait.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, shall I speak?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Why you would now think much
To be denied, but I can scarce entreat
What I would have: do, speak.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But will you hear me out?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: With me you article to talk thus: well
I will hear you out.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, that I have ever loved you, my sword hath spoken for me, that I do, if it be doubted, I dare call an oath a great one to my witness: and were you not my King, from amongst men, I should have chose you out to love above the rest: nor can this challenge thanks: for my own sake I should have doted, because I would have loved the most deserving man, for so you are.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Alas Mardonius, rise, you shall not kneel;
We all are soldiers, and all venture lives:
And where there is no difference in men's worths,
Titles are jests: who can out value thee?
Mardonius thou hast loved me, and haste wrong,
Thy love is not rewarded, but believe
It shall be better, more than friend in arms,
My father, and my tutor, good Mardonius.

sp.speaker: Mar ▪
sp.p: Sir, you did promise you would hear me out.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: And so I will, speak freely, for from thee
Nothing can come but worthy things and true.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Though you have all this worth, you hold some qualities that do eclipse your virtues.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Eclipse my virtue?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes your passions, which are so manifold, that they appear even in this: when I commend you, you hug me for that truth: when I speak of your faults, you make a start, and fly the hearing: but,

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: When you commend me? O that I should live
To need such commendations: if my deeds
Blew not my praise themselves above the earth,
I were most wretched: spare your idle praise:
If thou didst mean to flatter, and shouldst utter
Words in my praise, that thou thoughtst impudence,
My deeds should make 'em modest: when you praise,
I hug you; 'tis so false, that wert thou worthy
Thou shouldst receive a death, a glorious death
From me: but thou shalt understand thy lies,
For shouldst thou praise me into heaven, and there
Leave me enthroned, I would despise thee though
As much as now, which is as much as dust,
Because I see thy envy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: however you will use me after, yet for your own promise' sake hear me the rest.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I will, and after call unto the winds,
For they shall lend as large an ear as I
To what you utter: speak.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Would you but leave these hasty tempers, which I do not say take from you all your worth, but darken 'em, than you would shine indeed.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yet I would have you keep some passions, least men should take you for a god, your virtues are such.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why now you flatter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I never understood the word, were you no King, and free from these wild moods, should I choose a companion for wit and pleasure, it should be you, or for honest ▪ to interchange my bosom with, it would be you; or wisdom to to give me counsel, I would pick out you: or valour to defend my reputation, still I would find out you, for you are fit to fight for all the world, if it could come in question: now I have spoke, consider to yourself, find out a use? if so, then what shall fall to me is not material.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Is not material: more than ten such lives
As mine Mardonius: it was nobly said,
Thou hast spoke truth, and boldly, such a truth
As might offend another. I have been
Too passionate, and idle, thou shalt see
A swift amendment: but I want those parts
you praise me for: I fight for all the world:
Give thee a sword, and thou wilt go as far
Beyond me, as thou art beyond in years,
I know thou dar'st, and wilt; it troubles me
That I should use so rough a phrase to thee,
Impute it to my folly, what thou wilt,
So thou wilt pardon me; that thou and I
Should differ thus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why 'tis no matter sir:

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Faith but 'tis, but thou dost ever take
All things I do thus patiently, for which
I never can requite thee but with love,
And that thou shalt be sure of. Thou and I
Have not been merry lately: pray thee tell me
Where hadst thou that same jewel in thine care?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why at the taking of a town.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: A wench upon my life, a wench Mardonius
Gave thee that jewel.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Wench, they respect not me, I'm old and rough, and every limb about me, but that which should grows stiffer: lth those businesses I may swear I am truely honest: for I pay justly for what I take, and would be glad to be at a certainty.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why do the wenches encroach upon thee?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I by this light do they.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Didst thou sit at an old rent with 'em?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ye● faith.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: And do they improve themselves?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ay, ten shillings to me, every new young fellow they come acquainted with.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: How canst live on't?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why I think I must petition to you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Thou shalt take 'em up at my price.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Your price?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I at the King's price.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That may be more than I am worth.

sp.speaker: 1 gent
sp.p: Is he not merry now?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: I think not.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: He is, he is, we'll show ourselves.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Bessus I thought you had been in Iberia by this, bad you haste ▪ Gobrias will want entertainment for me.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: An't please your majesty I have a suit.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Is't not lousy Bessus, what is't?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I am to carry a lady with me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Then thou hast two suits.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: And if I can prefer her to the lady Panthan your majesty's sister, to learn fashions as her friends term it, it will be worth something to me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: So many nights lodgings as 'tis thither, will not?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I know not that, but gold I shall be sure of.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why thou shalt bid her entertain her from me, so thou wilt resolve me one thing.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: If I can.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Faith 'tis a very disputable question, yet I think thou canst decide it ▪

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Your majesty has a good opinion of my understanding.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I have so good an opinion of it: 'tis whether thou be valiant.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: somebody has traduce me to you: do you see this sword sir?

sp.speaker: Arb ▪
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: If I do not make my backbiters eat it to a knife within this week, say I am not valiant.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Health to your majesty.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: From Gobrias?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: How does he, is he well?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: In perfect health.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Thank thee for thy good news,
A trustier servant to his prince there lives not
Then is good Gobrias.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: The King starts back.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: His blood goes back as fast:

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: And now it comes again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He alters strangely.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: The hand of heaven is on me, be it far
From me to struggle; if my secret sins
Have pulled this curse upon me, lend me tears.
Enough to wash me white, that I may feel
A childlike innocence within my breast;
Which once performed, oh give me leave to stand
As fixed as constancy herself, my eyes
Set here unmoved, regardless of the world,
Though thousand miseries encompass me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This is strange, sir, how do you?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Mardonius my mother:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Is she dead?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Alas, she's not so happy; thou dost know
How she hath laboured since my father died
To take by treason hence this loathed life,
That would but be to serve her, I have pardoned
And pardoned, and by that have made her fit
To practise new sins, not repent the old;
She now has hired a slave to come from thence
And strike me here, whom Gobrias sifting out,
Took, and condemned, and executed there
The carefulst servant: heaven let me but live
To pay that man; nature is poor to me,
That will not let me have as many deaths
As are the times that he hath saved my life,
That I might die 'em over all for him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir let her bear her sins on her own head,
Vex not yourself.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: What will the world
Conceive of me? with what unnatural sins
Will they suppose me laden, when my life
Is sought by her that gave it to the world?
But yet he writes me comfort here, my sister
He says is grown in beauty, and in grace,
In all the innocent virtues that become
A tender spotless maid: she stains her cheeks
With mourning tears to purge her mother's ill,
And amongst her sacred dew she mingles prayers,
her pure oblations for my safe return:
If I have lost the duty of a son,
If any pomp or vanity of state
Made me forget my natural offices;
Nay farther, if I have not every night
Expostulated with my wand'ring thoughts,
If ought unto my parent they have erred,
And called 'em back: do you direct her arm
Unto this foul dissembling heart of mine:
But if I have been just to her, send out
Your power to compass me, and hold me safe
From searching treason; I will use no means
But prayers: for rather suffer me to see
From mine own veins issue a deadly flood,
Then wash my dangers off with mother's blood:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I ne'er saw such sudden extremities.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Why, wilt thou have me die Spaconia,
What should I do?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Nay, let me stay alone,
And when you see Armenia again,
You shall behold a tomb more worth than I,
Some friend that either loves me, or my cause,
Will build me something to distinguish me
From other women: many a weeping verse
He will lay on, and much lament those maids
That place their loves unfortunately 〈◊〉 hight,
As I have done, where they can never reach:
But why should you go to Iberia?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Alas, that thou wilt ask me; ask the man
That rages in a fever, why he lies
Distempered there, when all the other youths
Are coursing o'er the meadows with their loves?
Can I resist it? am I not a slave
To him that conquered me?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: That conquered thee, Tigranes he has won but half of
Thy body; but thy mind may be as free
As his, his will did never combat thine,
and take it prisoner:

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: But if he by force
Convey my body hence, what helps it me
Or thee to be unwilling?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: O Tigranes,
I know you are to see a lady there,
To see, and like I fear: perhaps the hope
Of her makes you forget me ere we part,
Be happier than you know to wish: farewell.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Spaconia stay, and hear me what I say:
In short destruction meet me, that I may
See it, and not avoid it when I leave
To be thy faithful lover: part with me
Thou shalt not, there are none that know our love;
And I have given gold to a captain
That goes unto Iberia from the King,
That he would place a lady of our land
With the King's sister that is offered me;
Thither shall you, and being once got in,
Persuade her by what subtle means you can
To be as backward in her love as I.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Can you imagine that a longing maid
When she beholds you, can be pulled away
With words from loving you?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Dispraise my health,
My honesty, and tell her I am jealous:

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Why, I had rather lose you: can my heart
Consent to let my tongue throw out such words,
And I that ever yet spoke what I thought,
Shall find it such a thing at first to lie:

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Yet do thy best.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: What is your majesty ready?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: There is the lady captain.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Sweet lady by your leave, I could wish myself more full of courtship for your fair sake.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Sir I shall find no want of that.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Lady, you must haste, I have received new letters from the King, that requires more speed than I expected he
will follow me suddenly himself, and begins to call for your majesty already.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: He shall not do so long.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Sweet lady shall I call you my charge hereafter?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: I will not take upon me to govern your tongue sir, you shall call me what you please:

div.head: Actus secundus scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Gobrias, Bacurius, Arane, Panthaea, and Mandane, waiting women, with attendance.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: My lord Bacurius, you must have regard
Unto the Queen, she is your prisoner,
'Tis at your peril if she make escape.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: My lord I know't, she is my prisoner
From you committed; yet she is a woman,
And so I keep her safe: you will not urge me
To keep her close, I shall not shame to say
I sorrow for her.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: So do I my lord.
I sorrow for her that so little grace
Doth govern her, that she should stretch her arm
Against her King, so little womanhood
And natural goodness, as to think the death
Of her own son.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.l: Thou knowest the reason why,
Dissembling as thou art, and wilt not speak.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: There is a lady takes not after you,
Her father is within her, that good man
Whose tears paid down his sins, mark how she weeps,
How well it does become her; and if you
Can find no disposition in yourself
To sorrow, yet by gracefulness in her
Find out the way, and by your reason weep:
All this she does for you, and more she needs,
When for yourself you will not lose a tear,
think how this want of grief discredits you,
And you will weep, because you cannot weep:

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.l: You talk to me as having got a time
Fit for your purpose; but you know I know
You speak not what you think.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I would my heart
Were stone, before my softness should be urged
Against my mother, a more troubled thought
No virgin bears about her; should I excuse
My mother's fault, I should let light a life,
In losing which, a brother and a King
Were taken from me; if I seek to save
That life so loved, I lose another life
That gave me being, I shall lose a mother,
A word of such a sound in a child's ear,
That it strikes reverence through it: may the will
Of heaven be done, and if one needs must fall,
Take a poor virgin's life to answer all.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.l: But Gobrias let us talk; you know this fault
Is not in me as in another woman ▪

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: I know it is not:

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Yet you make it so.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Why, is not all that's past beyond your help?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I know it is.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Nay, should you publish it
Before the world, think you 'twill be believed?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I know it would not.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Nay, should I join with you,
Should we not both be torn? and yet both die
Uncredited?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I think we should.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Why then
Take you such violent courses? as for me,
I do but right in saving of the King
From all your plots.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: The King?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: I bade you rest with patience, and a time
Would come for me
to reconcile all to your own content:
But by this way you take away my power,
And what was done unknown, was not by me,
But you, your urging, being done,
I must preserve mine own; but time may bring
All this to light, and happily for all.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.l: Accursed be this overcurious brain,
That gave that plot a birth; accursed this womb,
That after did conceive to my disgrace.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: My lord protector, they say there are divers letters come from Armenia that Bessus has done good service, and brought again a day by his particular valour: received you any to that effect?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis most certain.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I'm sorry fort, not that the day was won, but that 'twas won by him; we held him here a coward, he did me wrong once, at which I laughed, and so did all the world: for, nor I, nor any other held time worth my sword.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Health to my lord protector, from the King these letters, and to your grace madam these:

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: How does his majesty?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: As well as conquest by his own means, and his valiant commanders can make him ▪ your letters will tell you all.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I will not open mine til● do know
My brother's health; good captain is he well?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: As the rest of us that fought are:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: But how's that, is he hurt?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: He's a strange soldier that gets not a knock,

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I do not ask how strange that soldier is that gets no hurt; but whether he have one?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: He had divers.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: And is he well again?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Well again, an't please your grace; why I was run twice through the body, and shot ith' head with a cross arrow, and yet am well again.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I do not care how thou dost, is he well?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Not care how I do, let a man out of the mightiness
of his spirit fructify foreign countries with his blood for the good of his own, and thus he shall be answered: why, I may live to relieve with spear and shield such a lady distressed.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Why, I will care, I am glad that thou art well; I prithee is he so?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: The King is well, and will be here tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: My prayers are heard; now I will open mine.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Bacurius, I must ease you of your charge:
Madam, the wonted mercy of the King
That overtakes your faults, has met with this,
And struck it out; he has forgiven you freely,
Your own will is your law, be where you please ▪

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I thank him

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: You will be ready
To wait upon his majesty tomorrow?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: Madam, be wise hereafter:
I am glad I have lost this office.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Good captain Bessus, tell us the discourse
Between Tigranes and our King, and how
We got the victory.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I prithee do,
And if my brother were in any danger,
Let not thy tale make him abide there long,
Before thou bring him off; for all that while
My heart will beat.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Madam, let what will beat, I must tell truth, and thus it was: they fought single in lists but one to one, as for my own part I was dangerously hurt but three days before, else perhaps we had been two to two; I cannot tell, some thought we had; and the occasion of my hurt was this, the enemy had made trenches.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Captain, without the manner of your hurt be much material to this business, we'll hear it some other time.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Ay, I prithee leave it, and go on with my brother.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I will, but 'twould be worth your hearing: to the lists they came, and single sword and gauntlet was their fight.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Alas.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Without the lists there stood some dozen captains of either side mingled, all which were sworn, and one of those was I: and 'twas my chance to stand near a captain of the enemy's side, called Tiribasus; valiant they said he was: whilst these two Kings were stretching themselves, this Tiribasus cast something a scornful look on me, and asked me whom I thought would overcome: I smiled, and told him, if he would fight with me, he should perceive by the event of that whose King would win; something he answered, and a scuffle was like to grow, when one Zipetus offered to help him: I —

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: All this is of thyself, I prithee Bessus
Tell something of my brother, did he nothing?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Why yes, I'll tell your grace; they were not to fight till the word given, which for my own part by my troth I was not to give.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: See, for his own part.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I fear yet this fellow's abused with a good report.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Ay, but I:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Still of himself.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Cried, give the word, whenas some of them said Tigranes was stooping, but the word was not given then: when one cosroses of the enemy's part held up his finger to me, which is as much with us martialists, as I will fight with you: I said not a word, nor made sign during the combat; but that once done.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: He slips o'er all the fight.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I called him to me, Cosros said I:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I will hear no more.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: No, no, I lie.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I dare be sworn thou dost.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Captain said I, 'twas so.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I tell thee, I will hear no further.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: No, your grace will wish you had.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I will not wish it: what is this the lady
My brother writes to me to take?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
An't please your grace this is she: charge will
you come nearer the princes?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You're welcome from your country, and this land
Shall show unto you all the kindnesses
That I can make it; what's your name?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Thalestris.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Y' are very welcome, you have got a letter
To put you to me, that has power enough
To place mine enemy here; then much more you,
That are so far from being so to me,
That you ne'er saw me.

sp.speaker: Bes
sp.p: Madam, I dare pass my word for her truth.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: My truth.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: Why captain, do you think I am afraid she'll steal?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I cannot tell, servants are slippery; but I dare give my word for her, and for her honesty: she came along with me, and many favours she did me by the way; but by this light none but what she might do with modesty, to a man of my rank.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: Why captain, here's nobody thinks otherwise.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Nay, if you should, your grace may think your pleasure; but I am sure I brought her from Armenia, and in all that way if ever I touched any bare on her above her knee, I pray God I may sink where I stand.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Above my knee?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: No ▪ you know I did not, and if any man will say I did, this sword shall answer: nay, I'll defend the reputation of my charge whilst I live; your grace shall understand I am secret in these businesses, and know how to defend a lady's honour.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: I hope your grace knows him so well already,
I shall not need to tell you he's vain and foolish:

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Ay, you may call me what you please, but I'll defend your good name against the world; and so I take my leave of your grace, and of you my lord protector, I am likewise glad to see your lordship well.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: O captain Bessus, I thank you, I would speak with you anon.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: When you please, I will attend your lordship:

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Madam, I'll take my leave too:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Good Bacurius:

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Madam, what writes his majesty to you?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: O my lord,
The kindest words, I'll keep 'em whilst I live
Here in my bosom; there's no art in 'em,
They lie disordered in this paper, just
As hearty nature speaks 'em.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: And to me
He writes, what tears of joy he shed to hear
How you were grown in every virtuous way,
And yields all thanks to me, for that dear care
Which I was bound to have in training you:
There is no princes living that enjoys
A brother of that worth.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: My lord, no maid longs more for any thing, or feels more heat and cold within her breast, than I do now, in hope to see him.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Yet I wonder much at this, he writes he brings along with him a husband for you, that same captive prince;
sp.l: And if he love you as he makes a show,
He will allow you freedom in your choice.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And so he will my lord, I warrant you
He will but offer, and give me the power
To take ▪ or leave.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Trust me, were I a lady I could not like
That man were bargained with before I choose him.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.l: But I am not built on such wild humours,
If I find time worthy, he is not less,
Because he ▪ s offered.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: 'Tis true, he is not, would he would seem less:

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: I think there is no lady can affect
Another prince, your brother standing by;
He does eclipse men's virtues so with this.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: I know a lady may, and more I fear
Another lady will.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Would I might see him:

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Why so you shall: my businesses are great,
I will attend you when it is his pleasure
To see you madam.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I thank you good my lord.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: You will be ready madam:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: I do beseech you madam send away
Your other women, and receive from me
A few sad words, which set against your joys,
May make 'em shine the more.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sirs leave me all.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: I kneel a stranger here to beg a thing
Unfit for me to ask, and you to grant,
'Tis such another strange ill laid request,
As if a beggar should entreat a King
To leave his sceptre and his throne to him,
And take his rags to wander o'er the world
Hungry and cold.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: That were a strange request.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: As ill is mine.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Then do not utter it.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Alas, 'tis of that nature, that it must
Be uttered, ay, and granted, or I die:
I am ashamed to speak it; but where life
Lies at the stake, I cannot think her woman,
That will not take something unreasonably
To hazard saving of it: I shall seem
A strange petitioner, that wish all ill
To them I beg of, ere they give me ought,
Yet so I must: I would you were not fair,
Nor wise, for in your ill consists my good:
If you were foolish, you would hear my prayer;
If foul, you had not power to hinder me:
He would not love you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: What's the meaning of it?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Nay, my request is more without the bounds
Of reason yet; for 'tis not in the power
Of you to do what I would have you grant.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Why then 'tis idle, prithee speak it out.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Your brother brings a prince into this land
Of such a noble shape, so sweet a grace,
So full of worth withal, that every maid
That looks upon him, gives away herself
To him for ever; and for you to have
He brings him: and so mad is my demand,
That I desire you not to have this man,
This excellent man, for whom you needs must die,
If you should miss him. I do now expect
You should laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Trust me, I could weep
Rather, for I have found in all thy words
A strange disjointed sorrow.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: 'Tis by me,
His own desire too, that you would not love him.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: His own desire, why credit me Thalestris
I am no common wooer: if he shall woo me,
His worth may be such, that I dare not swear
I will not love him; but if he will stay
To have me woo him, I will promise thee
He may keep all his graces to himself,
And fear no ravishing from me.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: 'Tis yet
His own desire, but when he sees your face,
I fear it will not be; therefore I charge you
As you have pity, stop those tender ears
From his enchanting voice, close up those eyes,
That you may neither catch a dart from him,
Nor he from you: I charge you as you hope
To live in quiet, for when I am dead
For certain I shall walk to visit him,
If he break promise with me: for as fast
As oaths without a formal ceremony
Can make me, I am to him:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Then be fearless,
For if he were a thing twixt God and man,
I could gaze on him; (If I knew it sin,
to love him) without passion: dry your eyes,
I swear you shall enjoy him still for me,
I will not hinder you; but I perceive
You are not what you seem: rise, rise, Thalestris.
If your right name be so.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Indeed it is not
Spaconia is name; but I desire
Not to be known to others:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Why, by me
You shall not, I will never do you wrong,
What good I can, I will; think not my birth,
Or education such, that I should injure
A stranger virgin: you are welcome hither.
In company you wish to be commanded,
But when we are alone, I shall be ready
To be your servant.

div.stage: Enter three men, and a woman.

sp.p: Come, come, run, run, run:
We shall outgo her.
One were better be hanged, then carry women out fiddling to these shows.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: Is the King hard by?
You heard he with the bottles say, he thought we should come too late, what abundance of people here is.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: But what had he in those bottles?
I know not.
Why, ink good man fool:
Ink, what to do?
Why, the King look you, will many times call for those bottles, and break his mind to his friends.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: Let's take our places quickly, we shall have no room else.
The man told us he would walk a foot through the people.
I marry did he.
Our shops are well look to now:
'Slife yonder's my master I think.
No, 'tis not he.

div.stage: Enter two citizens wives, and Philip.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Lord, how fine the fields be, what sweet living 'tis in the country.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Ay, poor souls, God help 'em; they live as contentedly as one of us.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: My husband's cousin would have had me gone into the country last year, wert thou ever there?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Ay, poor souls, I was amongst 'em once.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: And what kind of creatures are they for love of God?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Very good people, God help 'em:

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Wilt thou go with me down this summer, when I am brought a-bed?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Alas, 'tis no place for us.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Why prithee?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Why, you can have nothing there; there's nobody cries brooms.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: No truly, nor milk.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Nor milk, how do they?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: They are fain to milk themselves ith' country.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Good lord: but the people there I think will be very dutiful to one of us?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Ay, God knows will they, and yet they do not greatly care for our husbands.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Do they not, alas? In good faith I cannot blame them: for we do not greatly care for them ourselves. Philip I pray choose us a place.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: There's the best forsooth.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: By your leave good people a little:
What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I pray my friend do not thrust my mistress so, she's with child.
Let her look to herself then, has she not had thrusting enough yet; if she stay shouldering here, she may hap to go home with a cake in her belly.
How now goodman Squitterbreech, why do you lean so on me?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Because I will.
Will you sir saucebox?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Look if one have not struck Philip, come hither Philip, why did he strike thee?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: For leaning on him.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Why didst thou lean on him?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I did not think he would have struck me.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: As God save me la, thou art as wild as a buck, there is no quarrel, but thou art at one end or other of it.
It's at the first end then; for he will never stay the last.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Well stripling, I shall meet with you.
When you will.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: I'll give a crown to meet with you ▪
At a bawdy house.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Ay, you are full of your roguery; but if I do meet you it shall cost me a fall.

sp.l: The King, the King, the King, the King:
Now, now, now, now.

div.stage: Enter Arbaces, Tigranes, Mardonius, and others.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: God preserve your majesty.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I thank you all: now are my joys at full,
When I behold you safe my loving subjects;
By you I grow, 'tis your united love
That lifts me to this height:
All the account that I can render you
For all the love you have bestowed on me,
All your expenses to maintain my war,
Is but a little word: you will imagine
'Tis slender payment; yet 'tis such a word
As is not to be bought without our bloods;
'Tis peace.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: God preserve your majesty.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Now you may live securely in your towns,
Your children round about you; you may sit
Under your vines, and make the miseries
Of other kingdoms a discourse for you,
And lend them sorrows: for yourselves you may
Safely forget there are such things as tears;
and may you all whose good thoughts I have gained,
Hold me unworthy, when I think my life
A sacrifice too great to keep you thus
In such a calm estate:

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: God bless your majesty.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: See all good people, I have brought the man,
Whose very name you feared, a captive home:
Behold him, 'tis Tigranes; in your hearts
Sing songs of gladness, and deliverance.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Out upon him.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: How he looks.

sp.speaker: 3 woman
sp.p: Hang him, hang him, hang him.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: These are sweet people.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Sir, you do me wrong,
To render me a scorned spectacle
To common people.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: It was far from me
To mean it so: if I have ought deserved,
My loving subjects let me beg of you
Not to revile this prince, in whom their dwells
All worth of which the nature of a man
Is capable; valour beyond compare,
The terror of his name has stretched itself
Wherever there is sun: and yet for you,
I fought with him single, and won him too;
I made his valour stoop, and made that name
Soared to so unbelieved a height, to fall
Beneath mine: this inspired with all your loves,
I did perform, and will for your content
Be ever ready for a greater work.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The lord bless your majesty.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: So, he has made me amends now, with a speech in commendations of himself: I would not be so vainglorious.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: If there be any thing in which I may
Do good to any creature, here speak out;
For I must leave you: and it troubles me,
Thus my occasions for the good of you,
Are such as calles me from you; else my joy
would be to spend my days amongst you all.
You show your loves in these large multitudes
That come to meet me: I will pray for you,
Heaven prosper you, that you may know old years,
And live to see your children's children
Fate at your boards with plenty: when there is
A want of any thing, let it be known
To me, and I will be a father to you:
God keep you all.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: God bless your majesty.
Come, shall we go, all's done.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: I for God's sake, I have not made a fire yet:
Away, away, all's done.
Content: farewell Philip.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Away, you haltersack you:
Philip will not fight he's afraid on's face.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I marry am I afraid of my face.
Thou wouldst be Philip, if thou sawest it in a glass; it looks like a visor.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: You'll be hanged sirrah: come Philip, walk afore us homeward; did not his majesty say, he had brought us home peases for our money?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Yes marry did he.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: They are the first I heard on this year by my troth, I longed for some of 'em; did he not say we should have some?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Yes, and so we shall anon I warrant you, have every one a peck brought home to our houses.

div.head: Actus tertij scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: My sister take it ill?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Not very ill,
Something unkindly she doth take it sir,
To have her husband chosen to her hands.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Why Gobrius te● her; I must have her know
my will, and not her own must govern her:
What, will she marry with some slave at home?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: O she is far from any stubbornness,
You much mistake her, and no doubt will like
Where you will have her; but when you behold her,
You will be loath to part with such a jewel.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: To part with her, why Gobrius art thou mad? she is my sister ▪

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Sir, I know she is:
But it were pity to make poor our land
With such a beauty, to enrich another.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Pish, will she have him?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: I think she will sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Were she my father, and my mother too;
And all the names for which we think folks friends,
She should be forced to have him, when I know
'Tis fit: I will not hear her say she's loath.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Heaven bring my purpose luckily to pass,
You know 'tis just: sir, she'll not need constraint,
She loves you so.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: How does she love me, speak?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: She loves you more than people love their health
That live by labour; more than I could love
A man that died for me, if he could live again.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: She is not like her mother then?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: O no, when you were in Armenia,
I durst not let her know when you were hurt:
For at the first on every little scratch,
She kept her chamber, wept, and would not eat,
Till you were well; and many times the news
Was so long coming, that before we heard,
She was as near her death, as you your health.

sp.speaker: Arb ▪
sp.l: Alas poor soul, but yet she must be ruled;
I know not how I shall requite her well,
I long to see her; have you sent for her,
To tell her I am ready?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Sir, I have.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Sir, here's the Armenian King.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: He's welcome.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: And the Queen mother, and the prince's wait without:

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Good Gobrius bring them in,
Tigranes you will think you are arrived
In a strange land, where mother's cast to poison
Their only sons; think you you shall be safe?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Too safe I am 〈◊〉 ▪

div.stage: Enter Gobrius, Arane, Panthaea, Spaconia, Bacurius, Mardonius, and Bessus.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.l: As low as this I bow to you, and would
As low as to my grave, to show a mind
Thankful for all your mercies.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: O stand up,
And let me kneel, the light will be ashamed
To see observance done to me by you.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: You are my King.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: You are my mother rise;
As far be all your faults from your own soul,
As from my memory; than you shall be
As white as innocence herself.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.l: I came
Only to show my duty, and acknowledge
My sorrow for my sins; longer to stay
We'll but to draw eyes more attentively
Upon my shame: that power that kept you safe
From me preserve you still.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Your own desires shall be your guard.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.l: Now let me die,
Since I have seen my lord the King return
In safety, I have seen all good that life ▪
Can show me; I have ne'er another wish ▪
For heaven to grant, nor were it fit I should:
For I am bound to spend my age to come
In giving than kes that this was granted me.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Why does not your majesty speak?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: To the Princess.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Alas sir, I am fearful, you do look
On me, as if I were some loathed thing
That you were finding out a way to shun.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Sir, you should speak to her.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I know I am unworthy, yet not ill,
Armed ▪ with which innocence here I will kneel,
Till I am one with earth: but I will gain
Some words, and kindness from you.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Will you, speak sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Speak, am I what I was?
What art thou that dost creep into my breast,
And dar'st not see my face show forth thyself ▪
I feel a pair of fiery wings displayed
Hither, from thence; you shall not tarry there,
Up, and be gone, if thou beest love, be gone,
Or I will tear thee from my wounded flesh,
Pull thy loved down away, and with a quill
By this right arm drawn from thy wanton wing,
Write to thy laughing mother in thy blood,
That you are powers belied, and all your darts
Are to be blown away by men resolved
Like dust; I know thou fearest my words, away.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: O misery, why should he be so slow ▪
There can no falsehood come of loving her,
Though I have given my faith; she is a thing
Both to be loved and served beyond my faith:
I would he would present me to her quickly.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Will you not speak at all, are you so far
From kind words? yet to save my modesty
That must talk till you answer: do not stand
As you were dumb, say something, though it be
Poisoned with anger that may strike me dead:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Have you no life at all? for manhood's sake
Let her not kneel, and talk neglected thus;
A tree would find a tongue to answer her,
Did she but give it such a loved respect.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: You mean this lady, lift her from the earth;
why do you let her kneel so long? alas,
Madam your beauty uses to command,
And not to beg; what is your suit to me?
It shall be granted, yet the time is short,
And my affairs are great: but where's my sister?
I bade she should be brought.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What is he mad?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Gobrius, where is she?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Where is she man?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Who sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Who, hast thou forgotten? my sister.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Your sister sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Your sister sir?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Some one that has a wit, answer; where is she?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Do you not see her there?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: There.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: There, where?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Slight there, are you blind?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Which do you mean, that little one?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: No sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: No sir, why do you mock me? I can see.
No other here, but that petitioning lady:

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: That's she.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Sir it is she:

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: 'Tis false.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Is it?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: As hell, by heaven as false as hell,
My sister: is she dead? if it be so,
Speak boldly to me: for I am a man,
And dare not quarrel with divinity;
But do not think to cozen me with this:
I see you all are mute, and stand amazed,
Fearful to answer me; it is too true
A decreed instant cuts off every life,
For which to mourn, is to repine; she died
a virgin though, more innocent than sleeps,
As clear as her own eyes, and blessedness
Eternal waits upon her where she is:
I know she could not make a wish to change
Her state for new, and you shall see me bear
My crosses like a man; we all must die,
And she hath taught us how.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Do not mistake,
And vex yourself for nothing; for her death
Is a long life of 〈◊〉 I hope: 'tis she,
And if my speech deserve not faith, lay death
Upon me, and my latest words shall force
A credit from you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Which good Gobrius,
That lady dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: That lady sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Pish, this is tedious,
I cannot hold, I must present myself;
And yet the sight of my Spaconia,
Touches me, as a sudden thunderclap
Does one that is about to sin.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Away,
No more of this; here I pronounce him traitor,
The direct plotter of my death that names,
Or thinks her for my sister: 'tis a lie,
The most malicious of the world, invented
To mad your King; he that will say so next,
Let him draw out his sword, and sheath it here,
It is a sin fully as pardonable:
She is no kin to me, nor shall she be;
If she were any, I create her none,
And which of you can question this, my power
Is like the sea, that is to be obeyed,
And not disputed with: I have decreed her
As far from having part of blood with me,
As the naked Indians: come, and answer me,
He that is boldest now; is that my sister?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O this is fine.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.l: No marry is she not an't please your majesty:
I never thought she was, she's nothing like you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: No, 'tis true, she is not:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Thou shouldst be hanged.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sir, I will speak but once: by the same power
You make my blood a stranger unto yours;
You may command me dead, and so much love
A stranger may importune, pray you do;
If this request appear too much to grant,
Adopt me of some other family
By your unquestioned word; else I shall live
Like sinful issues that are left in streets
By their regardless mothers, and no name
Will be found for me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I will hear no more;
Why should there be such music in a voice,
And sin for me to hear it: all the world
May take delight in this, and 'tis damnation
For me to do so; you are fair, and wise,
And virtuous I think, and he is blessed
That is so near you as your brother is:
But you are naught to me but a disease,
Continual torment without hope of ease;
Such an ungodly sickness I have got,
That he that undertakes my cure, must first
O'erthrow divinity, all moral laws,
And leave mankind as unconfined as beasts,
Allowing them to do all actions
As freely as they drink, when they desire.
Let me not hear you speak again; yet so
I shall but languish for the want of that,
The having which would kill me: no man here
Offer to speak for her; for I consider
As much as you can say: I will not toil
My body, and my mind too, rest thou there,
Here's one within will labour for you both.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I would I were past speaking.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Fear not madam,
The King will alter, 'tis some sudden change,
And you shall see it end some other way.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Pray God it do.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Though she to whom I swore be here, I cannot
Stifle my passion longer: if my father
Should rise again disquieted with this,
And charge me to forbear, yet it would out:
Madam, a stranger, and a prisoner begs
To be bid welcome.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You are welcome sir
I think, but if you be not, 'tis passed me
To make you so: for I am here a stranger,
Greater than you: we know from whence you come,
But I appear a lost thing, and by whom
Is yet uncertain; found here in the court,
And only suffered to walk up and down,
As one not worth the owning.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: O, I fear
Tigranes will be caught, he looks methinks
As he would change his eyes with her; some help
There is above for me I hope.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Why do you turn away, and weep so fast,
And utter things that misbecome your looks,
Can you want owning?

sp.speaker: Spa
sp.p: O, 'tis certain so.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Acknowledge yourself mine.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: And then see if you want an owner,

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: They are talking.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Nations shall own you for their Queen.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Tigranes, art not thou my prisoner?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: And who is this?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: She is your sister.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: She is so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Is she so again, that's well:

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: And how dare you then offer to change words with her?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Dare do it, why you brought me hither sir
To that intent.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Perhaps I told you so,
If I had sworn it, had you so much folly
To credit it: the least word that she speaks
Is worth a life: rule your disordered tongue,
Or I will temper it.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Blessed be that breath.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Temper my tongue; such incivilities
As these, no barbarous people ever knew:
You break the law of nature, and of nations;
You talk to me, as if I were a prisoner
For theft: my tongue be tempered? I must speak
If thunder check me ▪ and I will.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: You will.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Alas my fortune.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Do not fear his frown, dear madam hear me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Fear not my frown: but that 'twere base in me
To fight with one I know I can o'ercome,
Again thou shouldst be conquered by me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He has one ransom with him already, methinks 'twere good to fight double, or quit.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Away with him to prison; now sir see
If my frown be regardless: why delay you?
Seize him Bacurius, you shall know my word
Sweeps like a wind, and all it grapples with ▪
Are as the chaff before it.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Touch me not.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Help there.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: It is in vain to struggle.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: You must be forced.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Sir, you must pardon us, we must obey.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Why do you dally there? Drag him away
By any thing.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Come sir.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Justice, thou oughtst to give me strength enough
To shake all these off: this is tyranny
Arbaces, subtler than the burning bulls,
Or that famed tyrant's bed. Thou mightst as well
Search in the depth of winter through the snow
For half starved people, to bring home with thee
To show 'em fire, and send 'em back again,
As use me thus.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Let him be close Bacurius.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: I ne'er rejoiced at any ill to him,
But this imprisonment: what shall become
Of me forsaken?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: You will not let your sister
Depart thus discontented from you sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: By no means Gobrius, I have done her wrong,
And made myself believe much of myself,
That is not in me: you did kneel to me,
Whilst I stood stubborn and regardless by;
And like a god incensed, gave no ear
To all your prayers: behold, I kneel to you,
Show a contempt as large as was my own,
And I will suffer it; yet at the last forgive me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: O you wrong me more in this,
Then in your rage you did: you mock me now.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Never forgive me then, which is the worst
Can happen to me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: If you be in earnest,
Stand up, and give me but a gentle look,
And two kind words, and I shall be in heaven.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Rise you then to; here I acknowledge thee
My hope, the only jewel of my life,
The best of sisters, dearer than my breath,
A happiness as high as I could think;
And when my actions call thee otherwise,
Perdition light upon me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: This is better
Than if you had not frowned, it comes to me
Like mercy at the block; and when I leave
To serve you with my life, your curse be with me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Then thus I do salute thee, and again
to make this knot the stronger; paradise
Is there: it may be you are still in doubt,
This, this third kiss ▪ blots it out. I wade in sin,
And foolishly entice myself along:
Take her away, see her a prisoner
In her own chamber ▪ closely Gobrius.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Alas sir, why?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I must not stay the answer, do it.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: No more, do it I say.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This is better and better.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Yet hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I will not hear you speak;
Away with her, let no man think to speak
For such a creature: for she is a witch,
A poisoner, and a prater.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Madam, this office grieves me.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis well the King is pleased with it.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Bessus, go you along too with her; I will prove
All this that I have said, if I may live
So long: but I am desperately sick,
For she has given me poison in a kiss;
She had it twixt her lips, and with her eyes
She witch's people: go without a word. Exeunt omnes, pr●.
Why should you that have made me stand in warAr. Mar.
Like fate itself, cutting what threads I pleased,
Decree such an unworthy end of me,
And all my glories? what am I alas,
That you oppose me? If my secret thoughts
Have ever harboured swellings against you,
They could not hurt you, and it is in you
To give me sorrow, that will render me
Apt to receive your mercy; rather so,
Let it be rather so, then punish me
With such unmanly sins: incest is in me
Dwelling already, and it must be holy
That pulls it thence; where art Mardonius?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I prithee bear me, if thou canst;
Am I not grown a strange weight?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: As you were.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: No heavier?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: No sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Why, my legs
Refuse to bear my body; oh Mardonius,
Thou hast in field beheld me, when thou knowest
I could have gone, though I could never run.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And so I shall again.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.p: O no, 'tis past.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pray ye go, rest yourself.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Wilt thou hereafter when they talk of me,
As thou shalt hear nothing but infamy;
Remember some of those things.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, I will.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I prithee do: for thou shalt never see me so again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
They talk of fame, I have gotten it in the wars, and will afford any man a reasonable pennyworth: some will say they could be content to have it, but that it is to be achieved with danger; but my opinion is otherwise: for if I might stand still in canon proof, and have fame fall upon me, I would refuse it: my reputation came principally by thinking to run away, which nobody knows but Mardonius ▪ and I think he conceals it to anger me. Before I went to the wars, I came to the town a young fellow without means, or parts, to deserve friends; and my empty guts persuaded me to lie, and abuse people for my meat, which I did, and they beat me: then would I fast two days, till my hunger cried out on me, rail still; then methought I had a monstrous stomach to abuse them again, and did it. In this state I continued till they hung me up by th'heels and beat me with hazel sticks, as if they would have baked me, and have cozened somebody with me for venison: after this I railed, and sat quietly: for the whole kingdom took notice of me for a baffled whipt fellow, and what I said, was remembered in mirth, but never in anger; of which I was glad,
I would it were at that pass again: after this, God called an aunt of mine, that left two hundred pounds in a cousin's hand for me, who taking me to be a gallant young spirit, raised a company for me with the money, and sent me into Armenia with 'em: away I would have run from them, but that I could get no company, and alone I durst not run. I was never at battle but once, and there I was running, but Mardonius cudgeled me; yet I got loose at last, but was so afraid, that I saw no more than my shoulders do, but fled with my whole company amongst my enemies, and overthrew 'em: now the report of my valour is come over before me, and they say I was a raw young fellow, but now I am improved. A plague of their eloquence, 'twill cost me many a beating: and Mardonius might help this too if he would; for now they think to get honour of me, and all the men I have abused, call me freshly to account, worthily as they call it, by the way of challenge.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Good morrow captain Bessus.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Good morrow sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I come to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: You are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: From one that holds himself wronged by you some three years since: your worth he says is famed, and he nothing doubts but you will do him right, as beseems a soldier.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: A pox on 'em, so they cry all.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: And a slight note I have about me for you, for the delivery of which, you must excuse me; it is an office that friendship calls upon me to do, and no way offensive to you, since I desire but right on both sides.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: 'Tis a challenge sir, is it not?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: 'Tis an inviting to the field.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: An inviting? O cry you mercy, what a compliment he delivers it with? he might as agreeably to my nature present me poison with such a speech: umh reputation, umh call you to an account, umh forced to this, umh with my sword, umh like a gentleman, umh dear to me, umh satisfaction: 'tis very well sir, I do accept it, but he must await an answer this thirteen weeks.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Why sir, he would be glad to wipe off his stain as soon as he can, sir upon my credit I am already engaged to two hundred and twelve, all which must have their stains wiped off, if that be the word before him.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Sir, if you be truly engaged but to one, he shall stay a competent time.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Upon my faith sir to two hundred and twelve, and I have a spent body too much bruised in battle, so that I cannot fight, I must be plain with you, above three combats a day: all the kindness I can do him, is to set him resolutely in my roll the two hundred and thirteenth man, which is something: for I tell you, I think there will be more after him, then before him, I think so pray ye commend me to him, and tell him this.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I will sir, good morrow to you.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Good morrow good sir. Certainly my safest way were to print myself a coward, with a discovery how I came by my credit, and clap it upon every post: I have received above thirty challenges within this two hours, marry all but the first I put off with engagement, and by good fortune the first is no madder of fighting than I, so that that's reserved. The place where it must be ended, is four days' journey of, and our arbitrators are there: he has chosen a gentleman in travel, and I have a special friend, with a quartern ague likely to hold him this time here, for mine; and when his man comes home, we are to expect my friend's health: if they would send me challenges thus thick, as long as I lived I would have no other living; I can make seven shillings a day oh th' paper to the grocers: yet I learn nothing by all these but a little skill in comparing of styles. I do find evidently that there is some one scrivener in this town, that has a great hand in writing of challenges, for they are all of a cut, and six of 'em in a hand; and they all end, my reputation is dear to me, and I must require satisfaction: who's there? more paper I hope; no, 'tis my lord Bacurius, I fear all is not well betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Now captain Bessus, I come about a frivolous matter, caused by as idle a report: you know you were a coward.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Very right.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: And wronged me.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: True my lord.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: But now people will call you valiant, desertlesly I think yet for their satisfaction, I will have you fight with me.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: O my good lord, my deep engagements.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Tell not me of your engagements, captain Bessus; it is not to be put off with an excuse: for my own part, I am none of the multitude that believe your conversion from coward.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: My lord, I seek not quarrels, and this belongs not to me, I am not to maintain it.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Who then pray?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Bessus the coward wronged you.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: And shall Bessus the valiant, maintain what Bessus the coward did?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I prithee leave these cheating tricks, I swear thou shalt fight with me, or thou shalt be beaten extremely, and kicked.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Since you provoke me thus far my lord, I will fight with you; and by my sword it shall cost me twenty pounds, but I will have my leg a week sooner purposely.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Your leg, why what ails your leg? I'll do a cure on you, stand up.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: My lord, this is not noble in you:

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: What dost thou with such a phrase in thy mouth?
I will kick thee out of all good words before I leave thee.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.l: My lord, I take this as a punishment for the offence
I did when I was a coward.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: When thou wert? confess thyself a coward still, or by this light, I'll beat thee into sponge.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Why I am one:

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Are you so sir, and why do you wear a sword then? Come, unbuckle, quick.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Unbuckle I say, and give it me, or as I live, thy head will ache extremely.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: It is a pretty hilt, and if your lordship take an affection to it, with all my heart, I present it to you for a newyears gift.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I thank you very heartily, sweet captain farewell.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: One word more, I beseech your lordship to render me my knife again.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Marry by all means captain, cherish yourself with it, and eat hard good captain; we cannot tell whether we shall have any more such: a due dear captain.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: I will make better use of this, then of my sword: a base spirit has this vantage of a brave one; it keeps always at a stay, nothing brings it down, not beating. I remember I promised the King in a great audience, that I would make my back-biter eat my sword to a knife, how to get another sword I know not, nor know any means left for me to maintain my credit but impudence: therefore will I outswear him and all his followers, that this is all is left uneaten of my sword.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll moan the King, he is most strangely altered; I guess the cause I fear too right, heaven has some secret end in't, and 'tis a scourge no question justly laid upon him: he has followed me through twenty rooms, and ever when I stay to await his command, he blushes like a girl, and looks upon me, as if modesty kept in his business: so turns away from me, but if I go on, he follows me again. See, here he is, I do not use this, yet I know not how, I cannot choose but weep to see him: his very enemies I think, whose wounds have bred his fame, if they should see him now, would find tears in their eyes.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I cannot utter it, why should I keep
A breast to harbour thoughts? I dare not speak:
Darkness is in my bosom, and there lies
A thousand thoughts that cannot brook the light;
How wilt thou vex me when this deed is done
Conscience? that art afraid to let me name it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How do you sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why very well Mardonius; how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Better then you I fear.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I hope thou art; for to be plain with thee,
Thou art in hell else: secret scorching flames
That far transcend earthly material fires,
Art crept into me, and there is no cure;
Is not that strange Mardonius, there's no cure?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, either I mistake, or there is something hid
