That you would utter to me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: So there is, but yet I cannot do it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Out with it sir, if it be dangerous I shall not shrink to do you service, I shall not esteem my life a weightier matter than indeed it is, I know 'tis subject to more chances than it hath hours, and I were better lose it in my king's cause, then with an ague. or fall, or sleeping to a thief; as all these are probable enough: let me but know what I shall do for you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: It will not out: were you with Gobrius,
And bade him give my sister all content
The place affords, and give her leave to send
And speak to whom she please?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes sir ▪ I was.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.l: And did you to Bacurius say as much
About Tigranes?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: That's all my business.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.l: O say not so,
You had an answer of all this before,
Besides, I think this business might be uttered
More carelessly.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Come, thou shalt have it out; I do beseech thee
By all the love thou hast professed to me,
To see my sister from me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, and what?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: That's all.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: That's strange, shall I say nothing to her?

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.l: Not a word;
But if thou lovest me, find some subtle way
To make her understand by signs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But what ▪ what should I make her understand?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: O Mardonius, for that I must be pardoned.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You may, but I can only see her then.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: 'Tis true;
Bear her this ring then, and on more advice
Thou shalt speak to her: tell her I do love
My kindred all; wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Mar ▪
sp.p: Is there no more?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: O yes, and her the best;
Better than any brother loves his sister: that's all.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Methinks this
Need not have been delivered with such caution;
I'll do it.

sp.speaker: Arb:
sp.l: There is more yet,
Wilt thou be faithful to me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir ▪ if I take upon me to deliver it,
After I hear it, he pass through fire to do it ▪

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I love her better than a brother ought;
Dost thou conceive me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I hope I do not sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: No, thou art dull, kneel down before her ▪
And ne'er rise again, till she will love me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, I think she does.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: But better than she does, another way;
As wife's love husbands.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why, I think there are few wives that love their
Husbands better than she does you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Thou wilt not understand me: is it fit
This should be uttered plainly; take it then
Naked as it is: I would desire her love
Lasciviously, lewdly, incestuously,
To do a sin that needs must damn us both;
And thee to ▪ dost thou understand me now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, there's your ring again; what have I done
Dishonestly in my whole life, name it ▪
That you should put so base a business to me?

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.p: Didst thou not tell me thou wouldst do it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes ▪ if I undertook it; but if all
My heirs were lives, I would not be engaged
In such a cause to save my last life.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: O guilt, how poor, and weak a thing art thou?
This man that is my servant, whom my breath
Might blow about the world, might beat me here
Having his cause, whilst I pressed down with sin
Could not resist him, dear Mardonius
It was a motion misbeseeming man.
And I am sorry for it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pray God you may be so: you must understand, nothing that you can utter, can remove my love and service from my prince. But otherwise, I think I shall not love you more. For you are sinful, and if you do this crime, you ought to have no laws. For after this it will be great injustice in you to punish any offendor for any crime: for myself I find my heart too big, I feel I have not patience to look on whilst you run these forbidden courses: means I have none but your favour, and I am rather glad, that I shall lose 'em both together ▪ then keep 'em with such conditions, I shall find a dwelling amongst some people, where though our garments perhaps be courser, we shall be richer far within, and harbour no such vices in 'em. God preserve you, and mend you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Mardonius, stay Mardonius, for though
My present state require nothing but knaves
To be about me, such as are prepared
For every wicked act ▪ yet who does know
But that my loathed fate may turn about,
And I have use of honest men again:
I hope I may, I prithee leave me not.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Where is the King?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: There.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: An't please your majesty, there's the knife.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What knife:

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: The sword is eaten.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Away you fool ▪ the King is serious,
And cannot now admit your vanities.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Vanities, I am no honest man if my enemies have not brought it to this, what, do you think I lie?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: No, no, 'tis well Bessus, 'tis very well,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am glad on't.
If your enemies brought it to that, your enemies are cutlers,
Come, leave the King.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.l: No, let him stay Mardonius, let him stay,
I have occasions with him very weighty,
And I can spare you now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why I can spare you now.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Mardonius give way to the state affairs

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Indeed you are fitter for his present purpose.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Bessus I should employ thee; wilt thou do't

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Do for you, by this air I will do any thing without exception, be it a good, bad, or indifferent thing ▪

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Do not swear.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.l: By this light but I will,
Any thing whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: But I shall name a thing
Thy conscience will not suffer thee to do.

sp.speaker: Bes ▪
sp.p: I would fain hear that thing.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Why I would have thee get my sister for me:
Thou understands me in a wicked manner.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.l: O you would have about with her?
I'll do't, I'll do't i'faith.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Wilt thou, dost make no more ant?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: More, no, why is there any thing else, if there be tell me, it shall be done.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Hast thou no greater sense of such a sin?
Thou art too wicked for my company
Though I have hell within me, and mayst yet
Corrupt me further: pray thee answer me
How do I show to thee after this motion?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Why your majesty looks as well in my opinion as ever you did since you were born:

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: But thou appearest to me after thy grant
The ugliest, loathed, detestable thing
That I have ever met with. Thou hast eyes
Like flames of sulphur, which methinks do dart
Infection on me, and thou hast a mouth
Enough to take me in, where there do stand
Four rows of iron teeth.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
I feel no such thing, but 'tis no matter how I look, I'll do your business as well as they that look better, and
when this is dispatched, if you have a mind to your mother tell me, and you shall see I'll set it hard:

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: My mother, heaven forgive me to hear this,
I am inspired with horror: I hate thee
Worse than my sin, which if I could come by,
Should suffer death eternal, ne'er to rise
In any breast again. Know I will die
Languishing mad, as I resolve I shall,
Ere I will deal by such an instrument:
Thou art too sinful to employ in this;
Out of the world, away.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: What do you mean sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Hung round with curses, take thy fearful flight into the deserts, where amongst all the monsters,
If thou findst one foe beastly as thyself,
Thou shalt be held as innocent.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: If there were no such instruments as thou,
We Kings could never act such wicked deeds:
Seek out a man that mocks divinity,
That breaks each precept both of gods and man's,
And natures too, and does it without lust;
Meerely because it is a law, and good,
And live with him: for him thou canst not spoil.
Away I say; I will not do this sin.
I'll press it here till it do break my breast;
It heaves to get out: but thou art a sin
And spite of torture, I will keep thee in.

div.head: Actus quarti scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Have you written madam?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Yes, good Gobrias.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: And with a kindness, and such winning words
As may provoke him at one instant fee e
His double fault, your wrong, and his own rashness.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I have sent words enough, if words may win him
From his displeasure, and such words I hope
As shall gain much upon his goodness, Gobrius:
Yet fearing since they're many, and a woman's,
A poor belief may follow; I have woven
As many truths within 'em to speak for me,
That if he be but gracious, and receive 'em.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Good lady, be not fearful; if he should not
Give you your present end in this believe it
You shall feel (If your virtue can induce you
To labour out this tempest, which I know
Is but a poor proof against your patience ▪)
All those contents your spirit will arrive at
Newer and sweeter to you; your royal brother
(When he shall once collect himself, and see
How far ●e has been asunder from himself,
What a mere stranger to his golden temper)
Must from those roots of virtue, (Never dying
Though somewhat stopped with humour) shoot again
Into a thousand glories bearing his far branches
Hie as our hopes can look at straight as justice,
Laden with rich contents: he loves you dear,
I know it, and I hope I need not further
Win you to understand it.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I believe it,
Howsoever I am sure I love him dear,
So dear, that if any thing I write
For my enlarging, should beget high anger;
Heaven be a witness with me, and my faith
I had rather live entombed here.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: You shall not feel a worse stroke than your grief, I am sorry 'tis so sharp: I kiss your hand, and this night will deliver this true story with this hand to your brother.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Peace go with you,
You are a good man; my Spaconia
Why are you ever sad thus?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: O dear lady.
Many, and strange ones,
I feel my old fire flame again, and burn
So strong and violent, that should I see her
Again, the grief, and that would kill me 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: Your token I acknowledge, you may pass;
There is the King.

sp.speaker: Spac.
sp.p: I thank your lordship for it.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: She comes, she comes, shame hide me ever from her; would I were buried, or so far removed
Light might not find me out: I dare not see her.

sp.speaker: Spac.
sp.l: Nay, never hide yourself; for were you hid
Where earth hides all her riches, near her centre;
My wrongs without more day would light me to you:
I must speak ere I die; were all your greatness
Doubled upon you, you're a perjured man,
And only mighty in the wickedness
Of wronging women. Thou art false, false prince,
I live to see it: poor Spaconia lives
To tell thee thou art false; and then no more:
She lives to tell thee thou art more unconstant
Than all ill women ever were together;
Thy faith as firm as raging overflows,
That no bank can command; and as lasting
As boys gay bubbles blown in the air, and broken:
The wind is fixed to thee, and sooner shall
The beaten mariner with his shrill whistle,
Calm the loud murmurs of the troubled main,
And strike it smooth again; than thy soul fall
To have peace in love with any: thou art all
That all good men must hate, and if thy story
Shall tell succeeding ages what thou wert,
Oh let it spare me in it, lest true lovers
In pity of my wrongs burn thy black legend,
And with their curses shake thy sleeping ashes.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: O, o:
The destinies I hope have pointed out
Our ends alike, that thou mayst die for love,
though not for me: for this assure thyself,
The Princess hates thee deadly, and will sooner
Be won to marry with a bull, and safer,
Than such a beast as thou art: I have struck
I fear too deep; beshrew me fort: sir,
This sorrow works me like a cunning friendship,
Into the same piece with it; he's ashamed,
Alas ▪ I have been too rugged: dear my lord,
I am sorry I have spoken any thing,
Indeed I am, that may add more restraint
To that too much you have: good sir be pleased
To think it was a fault of love, not malice;
And do as I will do: forgive it prince,
I do, and can forgive the greatest sins
To me you can repent of; pray believe ▪ me.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: O my Spaconia! O thou virtuous woman!

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: No more, the King sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Have you been careful of our noble prisoner
That he want nothing fitting for his greatness?

sp.speaker: Bac ▪
sp.p: I hope his grace will quit me, for my care sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: 'Tis well, royal Tigranes' health.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: More than the strictness of this place can give sir I offer back again to great Arbaces.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: We thank you worthy prince, and pray excuse us,
We have not seen you since your being here,
I hope your noble usage has been equal
With your own person: your imprisonment
If it be any, I dare say is easy,
And shall not outlast two days.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: I thank you:
My usage here has been the same it was
Worthy a royal conqueror. For my restraint
It came unkindly, because much unlooked for;
But I must bear it:

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What lady is that Bacurius?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: One of the Princess women sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I feared it: why comes she hither!

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: To speak with the prince Tigranes.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: From whom Bacurius?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: From the Princess sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I know I had seen her.

sp.speaker: Mardo.
sp.l: His fit begins to take him now again
'Tis a strange fever, and 'twill shake us all
sp.p: Anon I fear; would he were well cured of this raging folly: give me the wars, where men are mad, and may talk what they list, and held the bravest fellows; this pelting prattling peace is good for nothing: drinking's a virtue to it:

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I see there's truth in no man, nor obedience,
But for his own ends, why did you let her in?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: It was your own command to bar none from him,
Beside the Princess sent her ring sir
For my warrant.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: A token to Tigranes, did she not:
Sirrah tell truth.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: I do not use to lie sir,
'Tis no way I eat or live by, and I think
This is no token sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This combat has undone him: if he had been well beaten, he had been temperate: I shall never see him handsome again, till he have a horseman's staff poked through his shoulders, or an arm broken with a bullet.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I am trifled with.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I know it, as I know thee to be false.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now the clap comes.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: You never knew me so sir, I dare speak it,
And durst a worse man tell me though my better.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis well said by my soul.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.p: Sirrah you answer as you had no life.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: That I fear sir to lose nobly.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.p: I say sir once again

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: You may say sir what you please.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Would I might do so.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I will sir, and say openly this woman carries letters, by my life I know she carries letters, this woman does it:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Would Bessus were here to take her aside and search
her, he would quickly tell you what she carried sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I have found it out, this woman carries letters.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: If this hold 'twill be an ill world for bawds, chambermaids, and postboys, I thank God I have none but his letters patents, things of his own inditing.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.p: Prince this cunning cannot do it.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: What sir, I reach you not.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: It shall not serve your turn prince.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: Serve my turn sir.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.p: ● sir it shall not serve your turn.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: Be plainer good sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: This woman shall carry no more letters back to your love Panthaea, by heaven she shall not, I sa she shall not.

sp.speaker: Mardo.
sp.p: This would make a saint swear like a soldier, and a soldier like termagant.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: This beats me more King than the blows you gave me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Take 'em away both, and together let 'em be prisoners, strictly and closely kept, or sirrah your life shall answer it; and let nobody speak with 'em hereafter.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Well I am subject to you, and must endure these passions.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: This is the imprisonment I have looked for always, and the dear place I would choose.
sp.stage: Ex. Bacu. with Tig. and Spa.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, have you done well now?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Dare you reprove it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: You must be crossing me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have no letters sir to anger you,
But a dry sonnet of my corporals
To an old saddler's wife, and that I'll burn sir:
'Tis like to prove a fine age for the ignorant.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: How darest thou so often forfeit thy life,
Thou knowest 'tis in my power to take it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, and I know you wonot, or if you do, you'll miss it quickly.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Who shall then tell you of these childish follies
When I am dead? Who shall put to his power
To draw those virtues out of a flood of humours
Where they are drowned, and make 'em shine again?
No cut my head off: do, kill me:
than you may talk, and be believed, and grow,
And have your too self-glorious temper rot
Into a dead sleep, and the kingdom with you,
Like foreign swords be in your throats, and slaughter
Be everywhere about you like your flatterers.
Do, kill me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Prithee be tamer good Mardonius,
Thou knowest I love thee, nay I honour thee:
Believe it good old soldier I am all thine:
But I am racked clean from myself, bear with me,
Wilt thou bear with me good Mardonius.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There comes a good man, love him too, he's temperate,
You may live to have need of such a virtue,
Rage is not still in fashion.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Welcome good Gobrius.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: My service, and this letter to your grace.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: From the rich mine of virtue, and all beauty,
Your mournful sister.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: She is in prison Gobrius, is she not?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: She is sir till your pleasure do enlarge her,
Which on my knees I beg; oh 'tis not fit
That all the sweetness of the world in one;
The youth, and virtue, that would have wild tigers
And wilder people, that have known no manners
Should live thus clpostered up, for your love's sake
(If there be any in that noble heart)
To her a wretched lady, and forlorn,
Or for her love to you, (Which is as much
As nature, and obedience ever gave)
Have pity on her beauties.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Prithee stand up, 'tis true she is too fair,
And all these commendations but her own:
Would thou hadst never so commended her,
Or I ne'er lived to have heard it, Gobrius;
If thou but knew of the wrong her beauty does her,
Thou wouldst in pity of her be a liar:
Thy ignorance has drawn me wretched man
whether myself nor thou canst well tell, oh my fate,
I think she loves me; but I fear another
Is deeper in her heart: how thinkst thou Gobrius?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: I do beseech your grace believe it not,
For let me perish if it be not false:
Good sir read her letter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This love, or what a devil is it, I know not, begets more mischief than a wake. I had rather be we I beaten starved, or lousy, then live within the air on't. He that had seen this brave fellow charge through a grove of pikes but tother day, and look upon him now, will ne'er believe his eyes again; if he continue thus but two days more, a tailor may beat him with one hand tied behind him.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Alas she would be at liberty,
And there be thousand reasons Gobrius
That will deny it:
Which if she knew, she would contentedly
Be where she is and bless her virtue for it,
And me though she were closer, she would Gobrius,
Good man indeed she would.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Then good sir for her satisfaction
Send for her, and with reason make her know
Why she must live thus from you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I will go bring her to me.

div.stage: Enter Bessus, and two swordmen, and a boy.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.l: You're very welcome both, some stools there boy,
And reach a table; gentlemen oth' sword,
Pray sit without more compliment: be gone child,
I have been curious in the searching of you,
Because I understood you wise, and valiant persons.

sp.p: We understand ourselves sir.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.l: Nay gentlemen, and my dear friends oth' sword,
No compliment I pray; but to the cause
I hang upon, which in few, is my honour.
You cannot hang too much sir for your honour,
But to your cause, be wise, and speak truth.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: My first doubt is my beating by my prince.

sp.l: Stay there a little sir, do you doubt a beating,
or have you had a beating by your prince.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Gentlemen ath' sword, my prince has beaten me.
Brother what think you of this case
If he have beaten him, the case is clear.

sp.l: If he have beaten him I grant the case;
But how? We cannot be too subtle in this business
I say, but how?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Even with his royal hand.
Was it a blow of love or indignation.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.l: 'Twas twenty blows of indignation gentlemen,
Besides two blows ath' face.
Those blows ath' face have made a new case on't,
The rest were but an honourable rudeness ▪

sp.p: Two blows oth' face, and given by a worse man, I must confess as we swordmen say, had turned the business: mark me brother, by a worse man; but being by his prince, had they been ten, and those ten drawn ten teeth, beside the hazard of his nose for ever; all these had been but favours: this is my flat opinion, which I'll die in.

The King may do much captain believe it, for had he cracked your skull through like a bottle, or broke a rib or two with crossing of you, yet you had lost no honour: this is strange you may imagine; but this is truth now captain.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.l: I will be glad to embrace it gentleman;
But how far may he strike me?
There's another,
A new cause rising from the time, and distance,
In which I will deliver my opinion:
sp.p: He may strike, beat, or cause to be beaten; for these are natural to man: your prince I say may beat you so far forth as his dominion reacheth; that's for the distance, the time, ten mile a day ▪ I take it.

sp.l: Brother you err, 'tis fifteen mile a day,
His stage is ten, his beatings are fifteen.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.l: 'Tis a the longest, but we subjects must
Be subject to it: you are wise, and virtuous.
Obedience ever makes that noble use on't,
To which I dedicate my beaten body;
I must trouble you a little further gentlemen oth' sword.
No trouble at all to us sir, if we may
Profit your understanding; we are bound
By virtue of our calling, to utter our opinions
Shortly, and discreetly.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: My sorest business is, I have been kicked.
How far sir?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Not to flatter myself in it all over, my sword forced, but not lost; for discreetely I rendered it to save that imputation.
It showed discretion the best part of valour.

sp.l: Brother, this is a pretty case, pray ponder on't,
Our friend here has been kicked.

sp.p: He has so brother.

sp.l: Sorely he says: now had he sit down here
Upon the mere kick, it had been cowardly.

sp.p: I think it had been cowardly indeed.

sp.l: But our friend has redeemed it, in delivering
His sword without compulsion; and that man
That took it of him, I pronounce a weak one,
And his kicks nullities.
He should have kicked him after the delivery,
Which is the confirmation of a coward.
Brother, I take it you mistake the question:
For say that I were kicked.
I must not say so;
Nor I must not hear it spoke byth' tongue of man
You kicked dear brother; you are merry.

sp.p: But put the case I were kicked?
Let them put it that are things weary of their lives, and know not honour: put case you were kicked?
I do not say I was kicked.
Nor no silly creature, that wears his head without a case, his soul in a skin-coat: you kicked dear brother.

sp.speaker: Bess ▪
sp.l: Nay gentlemen, let us do what we shall do
Truly and honestly; good sir toth' question.

sp.p: Why then I say, suppose your boy kicked captain?
The boy may be supposed, he's liable; but kick my brother?

sp.l: A foolish forward zeal sir in my friend;
But to the boy, suppose the boy were kicked?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: I do suppose it.
Has your boy a sword?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Surely no: I pray suppose a sword too.
I do suppose it: you grant your boy was kicked then.
By no means captain, let it be supposed still; this word grant, makes not for us.
I say this must be granted.
This must be granted brother?
Ay, this must be granted.
Still the must:
I say this must be granted.
Give me the must again, again; brother you palter.
I will not hear you wasp.
Brother, I say you palter, the must three times together; I wear as sharp steel as another man,
sp.l: And my fox bites as deep, musted my dear brother:
But to the cause again:

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Nay, look you gentlemen.
In a word I ha' done.

sp.l: A tall man, but untemperate; 'tis great pity:
Once more suppose the boy kicked.

sp.p: Forward.
And being thoroughly kicked, laughs at the kicker ▪
So much for us; proceed.

sp.l: And in this beaten scorn, as I may call it,
Delivers up his weapon: where lies the error?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.l: It lies ith' beating sir,
I found it four days since.
The error, and a sore one, as I take it;
Lies in the thing kicking.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: I understand that well, 'tis sore indeed sir.
That is according to the man that did it.
There springs a new branch: whose was the foo●e?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Ah lords.

sp.l: The cause is mighty, but had it been two lords,
And both had kicked you, if you laughed, 'tis clear.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.l: I did laugh,
but how will that help me gentlemen?

sp.p: Yes, it shall help you, if you laughed aloud.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: As loud as a kickt man could laugh, I laughed sir:

sp.l: My reason now; the valiant man is known
By suffering and contemning, you have
Enough of both, and you are valiant.
If he be sure he has been kicked enough:
For that brave sufferance you speak of brother,
Consists not in a beating, and away,
But in a cudgeled body, from eighteen
To eight and thirty: in a head rebuked
With pots of all size, daggers, stools, and bedstaves,
This shows a valiant man.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.l: Then I am valiant, as valiant, as the proudest,
For these are all familiar things to me:
Familiar as my sleep, or want of money.
All my whole body's but one bruise with beating,
I think I have been cudgeled with all nations,
And almost all religions.
Embrace him brother, this man is valiant,
I know it by myself he's valiant.
Captain thou art a valiant gentleman
To abide upon't, a very valiant man.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: My equal friends ath' sword, I must request your hands to this.
'Tis fit it should be.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.l: Boy get some wine, and pen and ink within:
Am I clear gentlemen?
Sir when the world has taken notice what we have done,
Make much of your body, for I'll pawn my steel,
Men will be coyer of their legs hereafter.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I must request you go along, and testify to the lord Bacurius, whose foot has struck me, how you find my cause.

sp.l: We will, and tell that lord he must be ruled,
Or there be those abroad will rule his lordship.

div.stage: Enter Arbaces at one door, Gob ▪ and panthaa at another ▪

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Sir here's the Princess.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Leave us then alone.
For the main cause of her imprisonment
must not be heard by any but herself:
You are welcome sister, and I would to God
I could so bid you by another name,
If you above love not such sins as these ▪
Circle my heart with thoughts as cold as snow
To quench these rising flames that harbour here.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Sir, does it please you, I should speak.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Please me,
I more than all the art of music can;
Thy speech does please me, for it ever sounds
As thou broughts joyful unexpected news:
And yet it is not fit thou shouldst be heard,
I prithee think so.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Be it so, I will.
I am the first that ever had a wrong
So far from being fit to have redress,
That 'twas unfit to hear it; I will back
To prison rather, then disquiet you,
And wait till it be fit.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: No, do not go,
For I will hear thee with a serious thought:
I have collected all that's man about me
Together strongly, and I am resolved
To hear thee largely, but I do beseech thee
Do not come nearer to me, for there is
Something in that that will undo us both.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Alas sir, am I venom?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Yes to me.
Though of thyself I think thee to be in
As equal a degree of heat, or cold
As nature can make, yet as unsound men
Convert the sweetest, and the nourishingst meats
Into diseases, so shall I distempered,
Do thee, I prithee draw no nearer to me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sir this is that I would, I am of late,
Shut from the world, and why it should be thus
Is all I wish to know.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Why credit me
Panthaea, credit me that am thy brother,
Thy loving brother, that there is a cause
Sufficient, vet unfit for thee to know,
That might undo thee everlastingly
Only to hear, wilt thou b●● credit this;
By heaven 'tis true, believe it if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Children and fools are ever credulous;
And I am both I think, for I believe:
If you dissemble be it on your head,
I'll back unto my prison ▪ yet methinks
I might be kept in some place where you are:
For in myself I find, I know not what
To call it, but it is a great desire
To see you often.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Fie, you come in a step, what doc you mean
Dear sister ▪ do not so: alas Panthaea,
Where I am, would you be, why that's the cause
You are imprisoned, that you may not be
Where I am.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Then I must endure it sir, God keep you.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.l: Nay, you shall hear the cause in short Panthaea;
And when thou hearst it, thou wilt blush for me,
And hang thy head down like a violet
Full of the morning's dew: there is a way
To gain thy freedom, but 'tis such a one
As puts thee in worse bondage, and I know,
Thou wouldst encounter fire, and make a proof
Whether the gods have care of innocents,
Rather than follow it; know I have lost
The only difference betwixt man, and beast,
My reason.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Heaven forbid.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Nay it is gone,
And I am left as far without a bound,
As the wild ocean that obeys the winds;
Each sudden passion throws me as it lifts,
And overwhelms all that oppose my will:
I have beheld thee with a lustful eye:
my heart is set on wickedness, to act
Such sins with thee, as I have been afraid
To think off: if thou dar'st consent to this,
(Which I beseech thee do not) thou mayst gain
Thy liberty, and yield me a content:
If not thy dwelling must be dark, and close
Where I may never see thee; for God knows
That laid this punishment upon my pride,
Thy sight at some time will enforce my madness
To make a start eye to thy ravishing:
Now spit upon me, and call all reproaches
Thou canst devise together; and at once
Hurl 'em against me: for I am a sickness
As killing as the plague, ready to seize thee.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Far be it from me to revile the King:
But it is true, that I should rather choose
To search out death, that else would search out me,
And in a grave sleep with my innocence,
Then welcome such a sin: it is my fate,
To these cross accidents I was ordained,
And must have patience; and but that my eyes
Have more of woman in 'em then my heart,
I would not weep: peace enter you again.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Farewell, and good Panthaea pray for me;
Thy prayers are pure, that I may find a death,
However soon before my passions grow,
That they forget, what I desire, is sin;
For thither they are tending: if that happen,
Than I shall force thee, though thou wert a virgin
By vow to heaven, and shall pull a heap
Of strange ▪ yet uninvented sins upon me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sir, I will pray for you ▪ yet you shall know
It is a sullen fate that governs us.
For I could wish as heartily as you
I were no sister to you ▪ I should then
Embrace your lawful love sooner than health.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Couldst thou affect me then?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: So perfectly
that as it is, I ne'er shall sway my heart
To like another.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Then I curse my birth,
Must this be added to my miseries
That thou art willing too, is there no step
To our full happiness, but these mere sounds
Brother and sister.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: There is nothing else
But these alas will separate us more
Than twenty worlds betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I have lived
To conquer men, and now am overthrown
Only by words, brother and sister: where
Have those words dwelling? I will find 'em out
And utterly destroy them, but they are
Not to be grasped ▪ let 'em be men or beasts,
And I will cut 'em from the earth, or towns,
And I will raze 'em, and then blow 'em up:
Let 'em be seas, and I will drink them off,
And yet have unquenched fire left in my breast:
Let 'em be any thing but merely voice ▪

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: But 'tis not in the power of any force
Or policy to conquer them.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Panthaea,
What shall we do? shall we stand firmly here, and gaze our eyes out?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Would I could do so;
But I shall weep out mine.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Accursed man,
Thou boughtest thy reason at too dear a rate;
For thou hast all thy actions bounded in
With curious rules, when every beast is free:
What is there that acknowledges a kindred
But wretched man? Whoever saw the bull
Fearfully leave the heifer that he liked,
Because they had one dam?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sir, I disturb you,
And myself too; 'twere better I were gone:
I will not be so foolish as I was.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Stay, we will love just as becomes our births,
No otherwise: brothers and sisters may
Walk hand in hand together; so will we
Come nearer: is there any hurt in this?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I hope not.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Faith there's none at all:
And tell me truly now, is there not one
You love above me?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: No by heaven.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Yet you sent unto Tigranes' sister.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: True, but for another: for the truth —

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.l: No more,
I'll credit thee; I know thou canst not lie,
Thou art all truth.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: But is there nothing else
That we may do, but only walk; methinks
Brothers and sisters lawfully may kiss.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: And so they may Panthaea, so will we,
And kiss again too; we were scrupulous
And foolish, but we will be so no more.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: If you have any mercy, let me go
To prison, to my death, to any thing:
I feel a sin growing upon my blood,
Worse than all these, hotter I fear than yours.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: That is impossible, what should we do?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Fly ●it for god's sake.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: So we must, away;
Sin grows upon us more by this delay.

div.head: Actus quinti scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, the King has seen your commission, and believes it, and freely by this warrant gives you leave to visit prince Tigranes your noble master.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: I thank his grace, and kiss his hands.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But is the main of all your business ended in this?

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: I have another, but a worse; I am ashamed, it is a business. —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You serve a worthy person, and a stranger I am sure you are; you may employ me if you please, without your purse, such office should ever be their own rewards.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: I am bound to your nobleness.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I may have need of you, and then this courtesy,
If it be any, is not ill bestowed:
But may I civilly desire the rest?
I shall not be a hurter, if no helper.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: Sir, you shall know I have lost a foolish daughter,
And with her all my patience; pilfered away,
By a mean captain of your Kings.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay there sir:
If he have reached the noble worth of captain,
He may well claim a worthy gentlewoman,
Though she were yours, and noble.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: I grant all that too: but this wretched fellow
Reaches no further than the empty name,
That serves to feed him; were he valiant,
Or had but in him any noble nature,
That might hereafter promise him a good man;
My cares were something lighter, and my grave
A span yet from me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I confess such fellows
Be in all royal campes, and have, and must be
To make the sin of coward more detested
In the mean soldier, that with such a foil
Sets of much valour: by description
I should now guess him to you. It was Bessus,
I dare almost with confidence pronounce it.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: 'Tis such a scurvy name as Bessus, and now I think 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Captain, do you call him?
Believe me sir, you have a misery
Too mighty for your age: a pox upon him,
you a valiant fellow for all this.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: My daughter is a whore,
I feel it now too sensible; yet I will see her,
Discharge myself of being father to her,
And then back to my country, and there die;
Farewell captain.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Farewell sir, farewell, commend me to the gentlewoman I pr●ia.
How now captain, bear up man.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.l: Gentlemen ath' sword your hands once more, I have been kicked again, but the foolish fellow is penitent,
Has asked me mercy, and my honour's safe.
We knew that, or the foolish fellow had better a kicked his grandsire.
Confirm, confirm I pray.

sp.p: There be our hands again.

sp.l: Now let him come, and say he was not sorry,
And he sleeps for it.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.l: Alas good ignorant old man, let him go,
Let him go, these courses will undo him.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: My lord your authority is good, and I am glad it is so, for my consent would never hinder you from seeing your own King. I am a minister, but not a governor of this state; yonder is your King, I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: There he is indeed,
And with him my disloyal child.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.l: I do perceive my fault so much, that yet
Methinks thou shouldst not have forgiven me.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: Health to your majesty.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: What? good Ligones, welcome; what business brought thee hither?

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: Several businesses.
My public business will appear by this:
I have a message to deliver, which
If it please you so to authorise, is
An embassage from the Armenian state;
Unto Arbaces for your liberty ▪
the offer's there set down, please you to read it.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.l: There is no alteration happened
Since I came thence?

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: None sir, all is as it was.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: And all our friends are well.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: All very well.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Though I have done nothing but what was good,
I dare not see my father: it was fault
Enough not to acquaint him with that good.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: Madam I should have seen you.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: O good sir forgive me.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: Forgive you, why I am no kin to you, am I?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Should it be measured by my mean deserts,
Indeed you are not.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: Thou couldst prate unhappily
Ere thou couldst go, would thou couldst do as well.
And how does your custom hold out here.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: Are you in private still, or how?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lig
sp.p: Do you take money? are you come to sell sin yet? perhaps I can help you to liberal clients: or has not the King cast you off yet? O thou vild creature, whose best commendation is, that thou art a young whore. I would thy mother had lived to see this: or rather would I had died ere I had seen it: why didst not make me acquainted when thou were first resolved to be a whore? I would have seen thy hot lust satisfied more privately. I would have kept a dancer, and a whole consort of musicians in mine own house, only to fiddle thee.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Sir I was never whore.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: If thou couldst not say so much for thyself thou shouldst be carted.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.l: Ligones I have read it, and like it,
You shall deliver it.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: Well sir I will: but I have private business with you.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: Speak, what is't?

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: How has my age deserved so ill of you,
That you can pick no strumpets in the land,
But out of my breed.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: Strumpets good Ligones?

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: Yes, and I wish to have you know, I scorn
To get a whore for any prince alive,
And yet scorn will not help methinks : my daughter
Might have been spared, there were enough beside.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.l: May I not prosper, but she's innocent
As morning light for me, and I dare swear
For all the world.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: Why is she with you then?
Can she wait on you better than your men,
Has she a gift in plucking off your stockings,
Can she make caudles well, or cut your corns,
Why do you keep her with you? For your Queen
I know you do contemn her, so should I
And every subject else think much at it.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.l: Let 'em think much, but 'tis more firm than earth
Thou seest thy Queen there.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: Then have I made a fair hand, I called her whore,
If I shall speak now as her father, I cannot of use
But greatly rejoice that she shall be a Queen: but if
I should speak to you as a statesman she were more fit
To be your whore.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.l: Get you about your business to Arbaces,
Now you talk idly.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: Yes sir, I will go.
And shall she be a Queen, she had more wit
Than her old father when she ran away:
Shall she be a Queen, now by my troth 'tis fine,
He dance out of all measure at her wedding:
Shall I not sir?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Yes marry shalt thou.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: I'll make these withered kexes bear my body
Two hearest gether above ground.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Nay, go ▪ my business requires haste.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: Good God preserve you, you are an excellent King.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Farewell good father.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: Farewell sweet virtuous daughter;
I never was so joyful in my life,
that I remember: shall she be a Queen?
Now I perceive a man may weep for joy,
I had thought they had lied that said so.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.l: Come my dear love.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: But you may see another
May alter that again.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Urge it no more;
I have made up a new strong constancy,
Not to be shaken with eyes; I know I have
The passions of a man, but if I meet
With any subject that shall hold my eyes
More firmly then is fit; I'll think of thee,
And run away from it: let that suffice.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Three gentlemen without to speak with me?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Yes sir. Bac. Let them come in.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: They are entered sir already.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Now fellows, your business, are these the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: My lord I have made bold to bring these gentlemen my friends ath' sword along with me.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I am afraid you'll fight then.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.l: My good lord I will not, your lordship is mistaken,
Fear not lord.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: Sir I am sorry fort.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I can ask no more in honour, gentlemen you hear my lord is sorry:

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Not that I have beaten you, but beaten one that will be beaten: one whose dull body will require lancing: as surfeits do the diet, spring and full. Stockfish? Now to your swordmen, what come they for good captain

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: It seems your lordship has forgotten my name.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: No nor your nature neither, though they are things fitter I confess for any thing, than my remembrance, or any honest man's, what shall these billets do, be piled up in my woodyard?

sp.speaker: Bes
sp.p: Your lordship holds your mirth still, God continue it: but for these gentlemen they come.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: To swear you are a coward, spare your book, I do believe it.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Your lordship still draws wide, they come to vouch under their valiant hands, I am no coward.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: That would be a show indeed worth seeing: sirrah be wise and take money for this motion, travel with it, and where the name of Bessus has been known, or a good coward stirring, 'twill yield more than a tilting. This will prove more beneficial to you, if you be thrifty, than your captainship, and more natural; men of most valiant hands is this true?

sp.l: It is so most renowned,
'Tis somewhat strange.

sp.p: Lord, it is strange, yet true; we have examined from your lordship's foot there to this man's head, the nature of the beatings; and we do find his honour is come off clean, and sufficient: this as our swords shall help us.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: You are much bound to your bilbo-men, I am glad you are straight again captain ▪ 'twere good you would think some way to gratify them, they have undergone a labour for you Bessus, would have puzzled Hercules, with all his valour.
Your lordship must understand we are no men ath' law, that take pay for our opinions: it is sufficient we have cleared our friend.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Yet here is something due, which I as touched in conscience will discharge captain; I'll pay this rent for you.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Spare yourself my good lord; my brave friends aim at nothing but the virtue.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: That's but a cold discharge sir for their pains.
O lord ▪ my good lord.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Be not so modest, I will give you something.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: They shall dine with your lordship, that's sufficient.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Something in hand the while; ye rogues, ye apple-squires: do you come hither with your botled valour, your windle froth, to limit out my beatings.
I do beseech your lordship.
O good lord.

sp.speaker: Bac:
sp.p: Sfoot, what a many of beaten slaves are here? get me a cudgel sirrah, and a tough one.
More of your foot, I do beseech your lordship.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: You shall, you shall dog, and your fellow beagle.
A this side good my lord.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Off with your swords, for if you hurt my foot, I'll have you flayed you rascals.
Mine's off my lord.
I beseech your lordship stay a little, my strap's tied to my codpiece point: now when you please.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Captain, these are your valiant friends, you long for a little too?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: I am very well, I humbly thank your lordship.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: What's that in your pocket slave, my key you mongrel? thy buttocks cannot be so hard, out with't quickly.
Here 'tis sir, a small piece of artillery, that a gentleman a dear friend of your lordships sent me with to get it mended sir; for if you mark, the nose is somewhat loose.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: A friend of mine you rascal, I was never wearier of doing nothing, then kicking these two soot-bales.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Here's a good cudgel sir.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: It comes too late; I am weary, prithee do thou beat 'em.
My lord this is foul play i'faith, to put a fresh man upon us; men are but men.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: That jest shall save your bones, up with your rotten regiment, and be gone; I had rather thresh, then be bound to kick these rascals, till they cried hold: Bessus you may put your hand to them now, and then you are quit. Farewell, as you like this, pray visit me again, 'twill keep me in good breath.
Has a devilish hard foot, I never felt the like.
Nor I, and yet I'm sure I ha' felt a hundred.
If he kick thus ith' dog-days, he will be dry foundered: what cure now captain, besides oil of bays?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Why well enough I warrant you, you can go.
Yes, God be thanked; but I feel a shrewd ache, sure he has sprung my huckle bone.
I ha' lost a haunch.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: A little butter friend, a little butter ▪ butter and parsley is a sovereign matter: probatum est.
Captain, we must request your hands now to our honours.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Yes marry shall ye, and then let all the world come, we are valiant to ourselves, and there's an end:
Nay, than we must be valiant; oh my ribs.
O my small guts, a plague upon these sharp toed shoes, they are murderers.

div.stage: Enter Arbaces with his sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: It is resolved, I bore it whilst I could,
I can no more, hell open all thy gates,
And I will through them; if they be shut,
I'll batter 'em, but I will find the place
Where the most damned have dwelling; ere I end,
Amongst them all they shall not have a sin,
But I may call it mine: I must begin
With murder of my friend, and so go on
To an incestuous ravishing, and end
My life and sins with a forbidden blow
Upon myself.

sp.speaker: Mardo.
sp.l: What tragedy is near?
That hand was never wont to draw a sword,
But it cried dead to something:

sp.speaker: Arb. Mar.
sp.p: Have you bid Gobrius come?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How do you sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Well, is he coming?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why sir are you thus?
Why does your hand proclaim a lawless war
Against yourself?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Thou answerest me one question with another,
Is Gobrius coming?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir he is.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I can forbear your questions then, be gone sir, I have marked.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Mark less, it troubles you and me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You are more variable than you were.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Today no hermit could be humblier
than you were to us all.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: And what of this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And now you take new rage into your eyes,
As you would look us all out of the land.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I do confess it, will that satisfy,
I prithee get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir I will speak.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Will ye?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is my duty,
I fear you will kill yourself: I am a subject,
And you shall do me wrong in't: 'tis my cause,
And I may speak.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Thou art not trained in sin,
It seems Mardonius: kill myself, by heaven
I will not do it yet; and when I will,
I'll tell thee then: I shall be such a creature,
That thou wilt give me leave without a word.
There is a method in man's wickedness,
It grows up by degrees; I am not come
So high as killing of myself, there are
A hundred thousand sins twixt me and it,
Which I must do, I shall come to't at last;
But take my oath not now, be satisfied,
And get thee hence.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am sorry 'tis so ill.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Be sorry then,
True sorrow is alone, grieve by thyself.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I pray you let me see your sword put up
Before I go; I'll leave you then.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Why so?
What folly is this in thee? is it not
As apt to mischief as it was before?
Can I not reach it thinkest thou? these are toys
For children to be pleased with, and not men;
Now I am safe you think: I would the book
Of fate were here, my sword is not so sure,
But I should get it out, and mangle that
That all the destinies should quite forget
Their fixed decrees, and haste to make us new
far other fortunes, mine could not be worse,
Wilt thou now leave me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: God put into your bosom temperate thoughts,
I'll leave you though I fear.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Go, thou art honest,
Why should the hasty errors of my youth
Be so unpardonable, to draw a sin
Helpless upon me?

sp.speaker: Gob
sp.p: There is the King, now it is ripe.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Draw near thou guilty man,
That art the author of the loathedst crime
Five ages have brought forth, and hear me speak
Curses incurable, and all the evils
Man's body or his spirit can receive
Be with thee.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Why sir do you curse me thus?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Why do I curse thee, if there be a man
Subtle in curses, that exceeds the rest,
His worst wish on thee. Thou hast broke my heart.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: How sir? Have I preserved you from a child,
From all the arrows, malice or ambition
Could shoot at you, and have I this for pay?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: 'Tis true thou didst preserve me, and in that
Wert crueler then hardened murderers
Of infants and their mothers; thou didst save me
Only till thou hadst studied out a way
How to destroy me cunningly thyself:
This was a curious way of torturing.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Thou knowest the evils thou hast done to me,
Dost thou remember all those witching letters
Thou sentest unto me to Armenia,
Filled with the praise of my beloved sister,
Where thou extol'st her beauty; what had I
To do with that, what could her beauty be
To me, and thou didst write how well she loved me,
Dost thou remember this: so that I doted
Something before I saw her.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: This is true.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Is it, and ● when I was returned thou knowest
Thou didst pursue it, till thou woundst me into
Such a strange, and unbelieved affection,
As good men cannot think on.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: This I grant, I think I was the cause.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Wert thou ▪ nay more, I think thou meantst it.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Sir I have a lie
As I love God and honesty, I did:
It was my meaning.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Be thine own sad judge,
A further condemnation will not need:
Prepare thyself to die.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Why sir to die?
Why wouldst thou live, was ever yet offendor
So impudent, that had a thought of mercy
After confession of a crime like this?
Get out I cannot, where thou hurlest me in,
But I can take revenge, that's all the sweetness
Left for me.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Now is the time, hear me but speak.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: No, yet I will be far more merciful
Than thou wert to me; thou didst steal into me,
And never gavest me warning: so much time
As I give thee now, had prevented thee
For ever. Notwithstanding all thy sins,
If thou hast hope, that there is yet a prayer
To save thee, turn, and speak it to yourself.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Sir, you shall know your sins before you do 'em if you kill me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I will not stay then.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Know you kill your father.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: You kill your father.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: My father? though I know it for a lie
Made out of fear to save thy stained life:
The very reverence of the word comes cross me,
And ties mine arm down.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: I will tell you that shall heighten you again, I am thy
father, I charge thee hear me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: If it should be so,
As 'tis most false, and that I should be sound
A bastard issue, the despised fruit
Of lawless lust, I should no more admire
All my wild passions: but another truth
Shall be wrung from thee: if I could come by
The spirit of pain, it should be poured on thee,
Till thou allowest thyself more full of lies
Then he that teaches thee.

sp.speaker: Arane.
sp.l: Turn thee about,
I come to speak to thee thou wicked man,
Hear me thou tyrant.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I will turn to thee,
Hear me thou strumpet: I have blotted out
The name of mother, as thou hast thy shame.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.l: My shame, thou hast less shame than any thing:
Why dost thou keep my daughter in a prison?
Why dost thou call her sister, and do this?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Cease thou strange impudence, and answer quickly,
If thou contemnest me, this will ask an answer,
And have it.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Help me gentle Gobrius.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Guilt dare not help guilt, though they grow together
In doing ill, yet at the punishment
They sever, and each flies the noise of other,
Think not of help, answer.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I will, to what?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: To such a thing as if it be a truth,
Think what a creature thou hast made thyself,
That didst not shame to do, what I must blush
Only to ask thee: tell me who I am,
Whose son I am, without all circumstance;
Be thou as hasty, as my sword will be
If thou refusest.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Why you are his son.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: His son?
Swear, swear, thou worse than woman damned.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: By all that's good you are.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Then art thou all that ever was known bad. Now is
The cause of all my strange misfortunes come to light:
What reverence expects thou from a child
To bring forth which thou hast offended heaven,
Thy husband and the land: adulterous witch
I know now why thou wouldst have poisoned me,
I was thy lust which thou wouldst have forgotten:
Thou wicked mother of my sins, and me,
Show me the way to the inheritance
I have by thee: which is a spacious world
Of impious acts, that I may soon possess it:
Plagues rot thee, as thou liv'st, and such diseases
As use to pay lust, recompense thy deed.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: You do not know why you curse thus.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Too well:
You are a pair of vipers, and behold
The serpent you have got; there is no beast
But if he knew, it has a pedigree
As brave as mine, for they have more descents,
And I am every way as beastly got,
As far without the compass of a law,
As they.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.l: You spend your rage, and words in vain,
And rail upon a guess: hear us a little.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: No I will never hear, but talk away
My breath, and die.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Why but you are no bastard.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Nor child of mine.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Still you go on in wonders to me.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Pray be more patient, I may bring comfort to you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I will kneel,
And hear with the obedience of a child;
Good father speak, I do acknowledge you,
So you bring comfort.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: First know our last King your supposed father
Was old and feeble when he married her,
and almost all the land as she passed hope
Of issue from him.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Therefore she took leave
To play the whore, because the King was old:
Is this the comfort?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: What will you find out
To give me satisfaction, when you find
How you have injured me: let fire consume me,
If ever I were whore.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Forbear these starts,
Or I will leave you wedded to despair,
As you are now: if you can find a temper,
My breath shall be a pleasant western wind,
That cools, and blasts not.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Bring it out good father,
I'll lie, and listen here as reverently
As to an angel: if I breathe too loud,
Tell me; for I would be as still as night.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Our King I say was old, and this our Queen
Desired to bring an heir; but yet her husband
She thought was passed it, and to be dishonest
I think she would not; if she would have been,
The truth is, she was watched so narrowly,
And had so slender opportunity,
She hardly could have been: but yet her cunning
Found out this way; she feigned herself with child,
And posts were sent in haste throughout the land,
And God was humbly thanked in every church,
That so had blessed the Queen, and prayers were made
For her safe going, and delivery:
She feigned now to grow bigger, and perceived
This hope of issue made her feared, and brought
A far more large respect from every man,
And saw her power increase, and was resolved,
Since she believed she could not have't indeed;
At lest she would be thought to have a child.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Do I not hear it well; nay, I will make
No noise at all; but pray you to the point,
Quick as you can.

sp.speaker: Gob
sp.l: Now when the time was full,
She should be brought a-bed; I had a son
Born, which was you: this the Queen hearing of,
Moved me to let her have you, and such reasons
She showed me as she knew would tie
My secrecy: she sware you should be King;
And oh be short, I did deliver you
Unto her, and pretended you were dead;
And in mine own house kept a funeral,
And had an empty coffin put in earth:
That night the Queen feigned hastily to labour,
And by a pair of women of her own.
Which she had charmed, she made the world believe
She was delivered of you: you grew up
As the King's son ▪ till you were six year old;
Then did the King die, and did leave to me
Protection of the realm; and contrary
To his own expectation, left this Queen
Truly with child indeed of the fair Princess
Panthaea: than she could have torn her heir,
And did alone to me yet durst not speak
In public; for she knew she should be found
A traitor, and her talk would have been thought
Madness or any thing rather than truth:
This was the only cause why she did seek
To poison you, and I to keep you safe:
And this the reason why I sought to kindle
Some spark of love in you to fair Panthaea,
That she might get part of her right again.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: And have you made an end now, is this all?
If not, I will be still till I am aged,
Till all my heirs are silver.

sp.speaker: Gob
sp.p: This is all.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: And is it true say you madam?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Yes God knows it is most true.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Panthaea then is not my sister. Gob no.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: But can you prove this?
If you will give consent: else who dare go about it.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Give consent?
Why I will have them all that know it racked
To get this from 'em: all that waits without
Come in, whate'er you be come in, and be
Partakers of my joy: oh you are welcome.
Mardonius the best news, nay, draw no nearer
They all shall hear it: I am found no King.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Is that so good news?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Yes, the happiest news that ere was heard.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Indeed 'twere well for you,
If you might be a little less obeyed.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: On, call the Queen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why she is there.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: The Queen Mardonius, Panthaea is the Queen,
And I am plain Arbaces, go some one,
She is in Gobrius' house; since I saw you
There are a thousand things delivered to me
You little dream of.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So it should seem: my lord,
What fury's this.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Believe me 'tis no fury,
All that he says is truth.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: 'Tis very strange.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.l: Why do you keep your hats off gentlemen,
Is it to me? In good faith it must not be:
I cannot now command you, but I pray you
For the respect you bore me, when you took
Me for your King, each man clap on his hat at my desire.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We will: but you are not found
So mean a man, but that you may be covered
As well as we, may you not?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: O not here,
You may but not I, for here is my father in presence,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Why there o the whole story
Would be a wilderness to lose thyself
For ever; oh pardon me dear father,
For all the idle, and unreverent words
That I have spoke in idle moods to you:
I am Arbaces, we all fellow subjects,
Nor is the Queen Panthaa now my sister.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Why if you remember fellow subject Arbaces, I told you once she was not your sister, I say she looked nothing like you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I think you did good captain Bessus.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Here will arise another question now amongst the swordmen, whether I be to call him to account for beating me, now he's proved no King.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Sir, here's Ligones
The agent for the Armenian King.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Where is he, I know your business good Ligones,

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: We must have our King again, and will.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I knew that was your business, you shall have
Your King again, and have him so again
As never King was had. Go one of you
And bid Bacurius bring Tigranes hither,
And bring the lady with him, that Panthaea
The Queen Panthaa sent me word this morning
Was brave Tigranes' mistress.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: 'Tis Spaconia.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Spaconia.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: She is my daughter.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: She is so, I could now tell any thing
I never heard; your King shall go so home
As never man went.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Shall he go on's head?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: He shall have chariots easier than air
That I will have invented; and ne'er think
He shall pay any ransom; and thyself
That art the messenger shall ride before him
On a horse cut out of an entire diamond,
That shall be made to go with golden wheels,
I know not how yet.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: Why I shall be made
For ever, they belied this King with us
And said he was unkind.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.l: And than thy daughter,
She shall have some strange think, we'll have the kingdom
Sold utterly, and put into a toy.
Which she shall wear about her carelessly
Somewhere or other.
See the virtuous Queen.
Behold the humblest subject that you have
Kneel here before you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Why kneel you
To me that am your vassal?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Grant me one request.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Alas, what can I grant you?
What I can I will.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: That you will please to marry me,
If I can prove it lawful.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Is that all?
More willingly, than I would draw this air.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I'll kiss this hand in earnest.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, Tigranes is coming though he made it strange
To see the Princess any more.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: The Queen,
Thou meanest: oh my Tigranes pardon me,
Tread on my neck I freely offer it,
And if thou beest so given; take revenge,
For I have injured thee.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.l: No, I forgive,
And rejoice more that you have found repentance,
Than I my liberty.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Mayst thou be happy
In thy fair choice; for thou art temperate:
You owe no ransom to the state, know that;
I have a thousand joys to tell you of,
Which yet I dare not utter, till I pay
My thanks to heaven for 'em: will you go
With me, and help ; pray you do.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Take then your fair one with you, and your Queen
Of goodness, and of us; oh give me leave
To take your arm in mine: come every one
That takes delight in goodness, help to sing
Loud thanks for me, that I am proved no King.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
